PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Funding of Children's Services
To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That funding in the area of childrens services, which has been reduced by almost 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-76 Budget. And further, that annual budget allocations in the area of childrens services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Free,Mr Leo McLeay,Mr Les McMahon and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the plan to obliterate the traditional weights and measures of this country does not have the support of the people.
That the change is causing and will continue to cause, widespread, serious and costly problems,
That the compulsory tactics being used to force the change are a violation of all democratic principles.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Metric Conversion Act be repealed to ensure that the people are free to utilize whichever system they prefer and so enable the return to imperial weights and measures wherever the people so desire;
That weather reporting be as it was prior to the passing of the Metric Conversion Act;
That the Australian Government take urgent steps to cause the traditional mile units to be restored to our highways;
That the Australian Government request the State Governments to procure that the imperial and metric systems be taught together in schools.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Anthony,Mr Chapman and Mr Fife.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the prospect of any legislation regarding plant variety rights.
The reasons are as follows:
1. We believe it would transfer control, the key aspect of agriculture in this country, to overseas interests not responsible to the Australian Government.
2. We believe it would restrict the growing and trading of many seeds.
3. We believe it would cause a decline in the genetic diversity of crops making them more subject to destruction by pests and diseases.
4. We believe thorough investigation of the effect of similiar legislation overseas and a full public debate is required before any decision is made.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament refrains from enacting any legislation on Plant Variety Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Jacobi,Mr Nixon and Mr Porter.

PETITION.TITLE: Confidential Medical Records
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are gravely concerned by the invasion of privacy caused by Government agents seizing patients' medical records.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, should-
Legislate to protect the private and confidential nature of medical records from scrutiny except on the express and informed consent of the patient or an order from a presiding judge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bungey and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That the right to work without discrimination on any ground including, inter alia, discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, pregnancy, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference, is a fundamental human right; and

That it is both the duty and the responsibility of society to fully support those denied work and therefore those who are unemployed as a result of society's inability to provide full paid employment should be guaranteed an adequate income without discrimination on any ground, including inter alia discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference, or pregnancy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray-

That appropriate and adequate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, in employment of individuals under federal awards, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to race, ethnic origin, marital status and/or sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hunt and Mrs Kelly.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned shows that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the prospect of the proposed Plant Breeders Rights Legislation.
The reasons are as follows:
1. P.B.R. will encourage the take-over of seed companies by chemical companies.
2. Will link available varieties to a particular package of agricultural fertilizers and pesticides.
3. Will reduce genetic diversity in seed lines for sale. We believe this legislation should be publicly debated and a referendum held before a final decision is made.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take positive action as soon as possible to arrest the implementation of such legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

a. Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

b. The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
c. The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognize that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
We express our grave concern at the terms of the Human Rights Commission Bill 1979 and the Racial Discrimination Amendment Bill 1979.

We note that strong opposition to the form of these Bills was expressed by the majority of our elected Senators. We note that the Bills only escaped amendment because a number of our elected Senators who opposed the Bills could not be in the chamber when the crucial votes were taken.

We note that the Human Rights Commission Bill is totally inadequate for a number of reasons which include the fact that the Bill does not permit the Commission to investigate breaches of human rights which occur under State law, e.g. Queensland or Western Australia. Further there is no power to prosecute violations of human rights.

We note that the Racial Discrimination Amendment Bill 1979 is also gravely deficient in a number of respects including the fact that the Commissioner for Community Relations loses his independence, powers and staff.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Legislature will listen to the voices of the Aboriginal and Ethnic communities, women and other disadvantaged groups, who are opposing these Bills in their present form.

We call upon the Legislature to ratify the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. But most importantly in the name of Democracy we call upon the Legislature to send the proposed legislation back to the Senate so that all our elected Senators are able to be present and vote on the legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the procedures used to determine eligibility for unemployment benefit (Work Test) are considered inappropriate in times of high unemployment.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament take note of the Norgard Review of the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Myer Inquiry into the Administration of Unemployment Benefit and make the necessary legislative changes to repeal the amended ''Work Test'' procedures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of the Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
Legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-

(1) That merchant seamen have in the past served in theatres of war; they have been decorated for valor following war action, they have been prisoners of war and should therefore be entitled to similar pension rights and medical benefits as regular servicemen.
(2) That by being denied the entitlements, such as pension and medical benefits, which other war veterans receive, they are thereby being discriminated against.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government amend the Repatriation Act (1920) Section 100 (d) (iv) to take account of war-related service by merchant seamen during World War II.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the interim list of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the island.
3. That the Queensland Government has recently renewed a further mining lease against the advice of conservationists.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Women's Advisory Council
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.
That the National Women's Advisory Council has not been democratically elected by the women of Australia;
That the National Women's Advisory Council is not representative of the women of Australia;
That the National Women's Advisory Council is a discriminatory and sexist imposition on Australian women as Australian men do not have National Men's Advisory Council imposed on them.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the National Women's Advisory Council be abolished to ensure that Australian women have equal opportunity with Australian men of having issues of concern to them considered, debated and voted on by their Parliamentary representatives without intervention and interference by an unrepresentative 'Advisory Council'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Recorded Music
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.
That the current rate of Sales Tax at 27 1/2 per cent on recorded music is unjust. We request that this rate be abolished or at least substantially reduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament assembled in the House of Representatives. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that.

Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Health Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.

That the continued cutback of our local community health centre will lead to a decline in the health status of our community. We appreciate their varied services, which include: baby health services, counselling, chiropody, physiotherapy, community nurses, preventative services etc.

We believe that the community health program will cut rising health costs by supporting people in their own homes. Therefore, we support the basic health care and prevention carried out by our health centre.
We request that adequate funding is provided for the continuation of and expansion of these valuable services to our community.
Your petitioners therefore, humbly pray that your honourable House consider this petition.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Airline Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That we protest most strongly against the present two airline domestic policy of the Commonwealth Government.
That this policy has resulted in expensive airfares and poor service and discourages tourists from the Eastern States visiting WA and vice versa.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will look favourably on our petition and formulate an Airline Policy providing for greater competition so that prices and service are determined by free market forces.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley,Mr N. A. Brown,Mr Bungey and Mr McLean.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Macquarie respectfully showeth:
That we consider the lack of service provided by Telecom Australia in Sydney's 047 telephone zone is not only inconvenient but is affecting families, business concerns and employment in the area.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government direct Telecom Australia to provide an adequate service to subscribers and users in the 047 telephone zone.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ballarat Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Ballarat and district respectfully showeth that the 1981 funding allocation for the Ballarat C.Y.S.S. project operating under the auspices of the Ballarat Y.M.C.A. is such that it will lead to a reduction of staff with a consequent loss of service to the young participants.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
(1) the funds be immediately restored to a level that will permit the maintenance of the project's current staffing;

(2) Public acknowledgement of the fact that the Ballarat C.Y.S.S. project requires maintenance of funding at 1980 levels, in real terms, if it is to continue serving existing clients efficiently, be made;
(3) a repudiation must be made of any policy that aims to save money at the expense of disadvantaged and unemployed youth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Humphreys proceeding to give a notice of motion-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The notice is out of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, because of Tasmania's heavy reliance on air travel, this House is of the opinion that air fares to and from that State should not be increased.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) condemns the Queensland Government for awarding an authority to prospect (a) to a consortium tenderer dominated by a foreign oil company and (b) on guidelines that were not made known to all parties;
(2) abhors veiled Queensland Government threats to other major tenderers concerning the release of bids; and
(3) urges the Federal Government to instigate a royal commission into the Queensland Government's handling of all mining development decisions in the last five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Is it a fact that reports of his own Department and also the Department of Trade and Resources indicate that a significant proportion of capital expenditure on mining projects will be spent on imports? For instance, is it a fact that one of these reports shows that such predominantly foreign-owned projects as the Alumax and Utah projects will be 50 per cent supplied from overseas while projects with greater Australian ownership source more equipment locally? Does this demonstrate the importance of having more Australian involvement in these potentially valuable enterprises as well as government influence to ensure that their benefits are spread to other Australians by equipment being sourced here, thus creating jobs in Australia instead of more profits being taken overseas? What action will the Government take to rectify this situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point made by the honourable gentleman is certainly well taken. He can be well assured that the areas in which he has indicated possible apprehension are very much in the Government's mind in its overall industrial development policies, particularly with respect to resource development. Subject to varying qualifications, the figure which has been put down for the extent of resource development before Australia during the years ahead presently stands at about $33 billion. Outside the direct impact which that resource development will have for the working of the Australian economy, there will be, as I am sure the honourable gentleman will understand, very significant spin-off effects for Australian manufacturing industry. In fact 70 per cent of this investment is likely to be spent locally on plant, equipment, wages and salaries, services and infrastructure support items. This will, of course, provide many diverse opportunities for manufacturing industry, particularly the fabrication and construction material sectors, for transport and for many other service industries generating, obviously, many new jobs in manufacturing and for Australia generally.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, a considerable amount of the equipment required in the resource development will come from overseas. That is natural, and I am sure the honourable gentleman would want the companies involved to select that equipment which is best for the projects concerned, whether that equipment is produced domestically or abroad. The honourable gentleman is very much aware of the firm guidelines which the Government has established to maximise Australian equity in the resource development boom.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer whether average weekly ordinary time earnings for full time non-managerial male employees grew by 15.2 per cent in 1980. Will that increase, which is substantially above the consumer price index increase for the same period, have a general inflationary impact especially on prices and interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Barker rightly reminds the House of the quite unacceptably fast rate of growth in wages that became evident when figures for increases during the December quarter were released recently. The rise in average weekly earnings has been revised upwards to 14 per cent and the earnings mentioned by the honourable gentleman rose at an even higher rate, by 15.2 per cent. It needs to be stated plainly that this development is one of the reasons the Government put to the Loan Council a proposal to increase the rate of interest on Australian savings bonds. It ought to be made plain to the critics of that decision that if wages continue to rise at a rate which is inimical to the economic recovery which is so clearly taking place elsewhere, the Government must respond with the tools that are available to it. One of those tools is the effective use of monetary policy.

ANSWER.PARA: I take this opportunity to put at rest some of the nonsense that has been put around in the last few days about the effect of interest rate rises on the availability of money for housing in Australia. That is something of importance to honourable members on this, and I hope on the other, side of the House. The facts are simply that over the three months to January, lending by the major institutions-that is, building societies and banks-was 1.2 per cent above the level of the previous three months and no less than 13.6 per cent above the level for the same period a year earlier. Those are the sorts of figures that ought to be kept in mind by honourable members when people charge in and suggest that the Government's interest rate policy is having an unsatisfactory, even drastic, effect on the availability of money for housing in Australia. The forces of supply and demand dictate that we, like any other borrower, have to offer competitive rates if we are to raise money. It is as simple as that. The Government does not intend to allow the critics of its monetary policy to get away with the totally false accusation that funds available for housing have dried up. The figures give the lie to that. There has been some restructuring between banks and building societies but the overall volume of funds available for housing remains at an extremely high level.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RESOURCE INDUSTRIES: EFFECT ON BALANCE OF PAYMENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Treasurer been drawn to Press reports of estimates, prepared by the Department of Trade and Resources, of the effects of expanding resource industries on the balance of payments? Does he agree with the Department that increased inflation and an appreciation of the Australian dollar are alternative responses to this expansion? Does he agree that these options would result in a 2.4 per cent increase in annual inflation or a 1.1 per cent annual increase in the value of the dollar, as estimated by the Department? What economic policies does he propose to pursue as an alternative to these unacceptable options?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The economic policies that I will continue to recommend to the Government are in substance the economic policies that have been followed over the past few years with gathering evidence of success. Insofar as external policies are concerned, the contribution made to the growing competitiveness of Australian industry by the management of the exchange rate in particular is something which is now very widely recognised, and it is one area of economic policy in which the wisdom of decisions taken by the Government some time ago has been vindicated with the passage of time.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite obviously the external policies that we followed have been highly successful, as indicated by the improved volume of private capital inflow into Australia, our much healthier external position and the fact that so far as our balance of payments is concerned, contrary to what was alleged from the other side of the House as recently as 12 months ago, the Government has not found it necessary to continue the very large borrowing program that was commenced in 1977. The prediction made then that that borrowing program was required to supplement a temporary shortfall in the volume of capital flowing into Australia has been demonstrated by the turn of events to be absolutely correct, and is another example of the success that we have had with the economic policies we have followed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Are certain skills possessed by military personnel deemed to be more important than others, particularly those involving specialist military technology? Does the cost of training men and women to operational levels warrant the striking and payment of graduated re-enlistment bonuses? If so, will the magnitude of any re-enlistment bonuses reflect the cost of training replacement personnel?

—The short answer to the first part of the honourable gentlemen's question is yes. In general terms the pay structure of the Services would reflect just that. I am bound to tell the honourable gentleman and the House that the re-engagement of specialists, particularly senior non-commissioned officers, is a matter that causes both me and the Services a great deal of concern because these highly trained and highly experienced men are, in Service terms, absolutely invaluable. I would like the honourable gentleman and the House to know that the Government is considering ways and means of possibly re-introducing a re-engagement bonus scheme which would-
—Was your earlier decision wrong?
—Unlike my honourable friend, I am quite prepared to say that I have made an error in my lifetime.
—To catalogue them all would take longer than Question Time.

—The honourable gentleman would still be walking to Canossa. I say to the honourable gentleman, yes, we are considering re-introducing a re-engagement bonus. As presently advised it will be done on a selective basis to ensure that the more valued skills are retained. I will keep the honourable gentleman and the House informed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer him to a statement in the Internal Research Memorandum No. 2 prepared by the Department of Trade and Resources, which reads:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . it has been estimated that in the period since the late 1960s only 2 per cent of domestic savings has been allocated to mining investment and clearly scope exists for local investors to play a more significant role in the development of Australia's natural resources.

I also refer the Treasurer to a proposal to establish a resources development fund, designed to provide the Australian public with an opportunity to invest in resource developments-an Australian Labor Party proposal, but similar to one supported by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. In the light of these proposals, does the Government intend to introduce such a scheme? If so, will the Treasurer acknowledge that this would be another example of a Labor initiated policy being used by the coalition parties?

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the honourable member for Isaacs that when the House last met I indicated both through a statement on taxation and in response to questions that the Government was anxious to maximise the opportunities available for Australians to participate, particularly by way of investment, in resource development. I said then, and I repeat for the benefit of the House, that one of the subjects that I believe the Commission of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System-which I imagine will be reporting to the Parliament in the course of this year-will be covering in some detail is the investment climate, particularly for small investors in Australia. It will also study constraints on those people and, generally, those aspects of the economy that affect investment including, I imagine, taxation. The Government makes no secret of the fact that it wants to see maximum opportunities reasonably available for Australians to invest. If it has the support of the Opposition in that aspiration, all the better. I would be anxious as far as possible to see a bipartisan approach to that sort of matter emerge in this House because all of us have an interest in maximising the opportunities for Australians to share in the development of our resources. I simply say to the honourable gentleman that, taking things in a logical sequence, we ought to see what the Campbell Committee has to say on that subject without prejudice to what other examinations the Government might wish to undertake on the subject.

—Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of a proposal by Mr Peter Russell-Clarke to have rural marketing authorities finance a national television program to promote Australian fresh food? If so, does the Minister think there is merit in such a proposal? Has Mr Russell-Clarke's previous promotional work on television been successful, and would a broader-scale promotion campaign be beneficial?

—Mr Russell-Clarke's efforts in advertising milk, eggs and cheese have been spectacularly successful. His work with the Australian Dairy Corporation has been first class. There is no doubt statistically that advertising has yielded a great benefit to the industry. Mr Russell-Clarke called to see me last week. On the basis of the success that he has had in the egg industry and in the dairy industry, he put to me a proposition that work of this sort ought to be spread on a wider basis to cover the fresh foods industry. There is no doubt that Mr Russell-Clarke has a high recognition rate and a high acceptance rate by television audiences. This is because he is a very credible person. He is a believable person because he tells the truth. The fact is that dairy products and eggs are good for you. If the honourable member for Adelaide were to concentrate his diet a bit more on real food and get away from eating fast foods and putting pork around the barrel he would be a much healthier person. I think Mr Russell-Clarke has a good proposition. I am having that proposition put to other primary industries that might be interested. We could talk about the grape industry-not the wine industry necessarily.
—What about wine?

—Wine sells itself for some reason. I do not need to expand on that. But certainly the proposition could interest the dried fruits industry, the beef industry and the lamb industry. Imagine what Mr Russell-Clarke could do with a barbequed lamb chop on television and how appealing such an advertisement could be. He put to me a serious proposition that all these food industries ought to come together in one big program that would have other components of interest to the viewing public. I think the project would have every element for success.

—I refer the Prime Minister to the Government's stated policy of not imposing the crude oil levy or a resources rent tax on production from the Fortescue oil field in Bass Strait. Given that State oil royalties are calculated on the basis of the price received by the producer, does this mean that Victorian Government royalties payable on Fortescue will be calculated on the full import parity price, presently at $30.23, rather than the existing producer price of around an average of $8 a barrel? Is this another example of a State collecting a tax for itself on a resource that is the property of the nation, particularly an off-shore resource for which constitutional control resides with the Commonwealth? What does the Government intend doing about this wellhead value question in relation to Fortescue to guarantee that the nation and not just Victoria benefits from this development?

—There are quite firm arrangements between the Commonwealth Government and the State of Victoria in relation to royalties. It is a matter that the Premier has raised with me in recent times. I will be responding at the appropriate time to whatever he might want to put. I make no further comment on that. The honourable gentleman introduced a somewhat detailed and technical question. I would like to look at it so that he might get a completely precise answer to the technical points that he put. I will therefore treat the main thrust of the honourable gentleman's question as being on notice.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. Has the New South Wales Minister for Health requested an additional $5m from the Federal Government to be made available to fund public hospitals in his State? What is the basis of such a request? Is it justified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noticed, as has the honourable member, statements emanating from the New South Wales Minister for Health, Mr Stewart, relating to an alleged crisis in the hospitals in that State. I was very interested in the basis of his claim that an extra $10m was needed. He was prepared to put up $5m if the Commonwealth was prepared to put up $5m. Naturally enough, I was very concerned about this statement. I thought it may have something to do with the projected State election, and talks of hospital crises may be gilding the lily a bit. So I checked to see the state of play in respect of New South Wales hospitals. In fact, the Commonwealth has made available about $475m to the State this year which is an increase of about 11.8 per cent on the funds made available in the previous year. So there is no question of a reduction of funds to hospitals in New South Wales or in any other State.

ANSWER.PARA: I checked further because there is a system whereby States request the Commonwealth to pay one month in advance the appropriations which are due. TALK.START.PARA: —Have you asked him?
—Yes, I have asked him. I sent him a telex yesterday to try to get his response.

ANSWER.PARA: The other fact that I would like to put before the House is that in 1979 Mr Stewart got in touch with the Commonwealth and asked whether the Commonwealth would agree to New South Wales introducing outpatient charges. It has taken him two years to try to work out these administrative arrangements. I hope for the sake of the hospitals there that he gets on with the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Transport noted yesterday's report by the New South Wales State Pollution Control Commission that large oil spills are inevitable in Botany Bay and that emergency services to deal with them are most inadequate? Finally, as Botany Bay was formerly regarded as the best equipped port in Australia for pollution control, does the present situation indicate that the national plan to deal with major oil spillages has now reached a stage of unmitigated disaster?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly I will deal with the oil spill possibilities in Botany Bay, which are primarly a matter for the State of New South Wales. We have a national plan in association with the States to assist the States should there be an oil spill within the waters under their control. We have also a plan for spills occurring outside the jurisdiction of the States. They come completely within the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth. At recent meetings of the Marine and Ports Council of Australia there have been discussions between the Commonwealth and the States about updating equipment and facilities where it was thought necessary and about examining the desirability of increasing the levy on shipowners to meet the costs of additional facilities that may be required.

ANSWER.PARA: I have asked my Department to submit to me the models of action that would be taken in the event of a spill in Botany Bay and on the open seas. I am quite satisfied that the Department, in association with the States, has a plan that could cope reasonably well with most situations. There is a need to ensure that the Government of New South Wales is also up to date with all the facilities and measures that are necessary so that it can cope with problems completely under its own jurisdiction. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

The Schools Commission did not make this known to me in its recommendation, nor was I informed until last Friday that the Acting Director-General of Education in New South Wales had written to the Schools Commission in early January to the effect that although his Department was happy to support the project he could give no guarantee that the materials produced would be used in New South Wales government schools. ANSWER.PARA: I am informed that an initial payment of $3,280 was made in January and that there is a balance remaining of $1,846. TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. Will the Minister table the documents from which he was quoting?

—I ask the Minister for Com- munications whether a job impact study has been conducted on the likely effect of the proposed communications satellite on the job security of the 1,800 Australian Telecommunications Commission employees working on maintenance and installation in the inter-capital network and the 3,000 employees working in similar areas in the rural network. What percentage of these workers would stand to lose their jobs if the satellite is interconnected with the terrestrial system? What does the Government propose to do to meet the needs of the workers in terms of continuing job security and/or retraining should they be made redundant as a result of that policy? Will the Minister assure the House that in the interest of security and privacy the communications system in this country will continue to operate under the common carrier system that now pertains? Will the Minister assure the House also that the economic viability of Telecom will not be called into question by the intrusion of some other body into the area of communications when all the evidence shows that that very limited market can take only one participant?

—I am appalled that the honourable member is prepared to intrude into the area of generating emotionalism about the impact of changing technology which is designed to bring the benefits of improved facilities to the Australian people. He is trying hard to generate fear among those who are presently employed in providing a network of communications around Australia. Our Government has demonstrated very effectively that it is a good employer. It has demonstrated concern for those who work within its employ. Its concern extends to those who pay the wages.

—I am interested to hear that honourable members on the other side of the House have no concern about the taxpayers of Australia. Our concern is to marry the provision of services with a level of taxation which the Australian people can provide. We will continue to do so in respect of the extension of the satellite system, as we will in every other field of government responsibility.

—I raise a point of order. Mr Speaker, in the past you have ensured that the answers of Ministers are relevant to the questions. There is no relevance between the sermon which the Minister is now reading to me and the likelihood of people becoming redundant as a direct result of the Government's policy.
—The answer is relevant.

—The Government is concerned about providing an improved level of communications around Australia. It believes that the introduction of the satellite will supplement terrestrial forms of transmitting a signal. We as a government are committed to ensuring the maximum benefit to the Australian public. In doing so, of course, we will be concerned about the impact on those who are employed, whether with Telecom Australia, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia) or any other government agency. Our prime concern, however, is to make sure that we meet adequately the communication requirements of the Australian people.

—My question to the Minister for Defence concerns external threats to Australia. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the evidence given last week by the Chief of Defence Force Staff, Admiral Sir Anthony Synnot, to the defence sub-committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence concerning possible threats to this nation? Has the Minister made an assessment of this evidence? What are current threats facing this country? I include those threats from Monday to Saturday as well as those on Sunday afternoon.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not yet had an opportunity to consider in the flat the evidence given by Admiral Synnot because the transcript of his evidence will not be available until, I believe, tomorrow afternoon some time. This is due to mechanical difficulties that face the Hansard people. But I am thoroughly familiar with Admiral Synnot's views on the issue. It is an issue I have discussed with him on many occasions. I simply say that the temptation to try to reduce the subject to simplistic terms should be avoided. There are some countries in the world-I emphasise 'some'; Australia is certainly not among them-which can reduce a threat to their national integrity to clear, simplistic terms. Australia cannot. Australia is not in that position. There are a great range of threats. I notice the honourable member for St George nodding assent. This is the case.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been just reading the report by Mr Brezhnev, the secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, to the 26th Congress of that party. It is a very substantial document. But it is a very clear asseveration of the basic Marxist-Leninist doctrine that world dominion remains the aim of the Communist Party. There is no ambiguity about it at all. Any person vaguely tutored in Marxism-Leninism will reach that conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Leninism, not Marxism.

—I am grateful to my honourable friend for his interjection and his reassurance that he is so alive. It is a term that Mr Brezhnev has used. I am quite sure that His Excellency the Russian Ambassador will be delighted to pass on to Mr Brezhnev the fact that the honourable member in the Australian Parliament now corrects the secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. The document lays out the program. To the extent that that ambition is pursued it remains a threat to the entire world. The fact that in the last 12 months the Soviet Union has moved more fighter interceptor aircraft into its Far Eastern inventory than the United States of America holds in the whole of its Pacific Air Force is, pro tanto to those countries involved, a clear threat. The fact that this year the Soviet Union is spending some $50 billion more on procurement, on military construction and on research and development than the United States of America is a threat to the nations of the world. There is only one other authority that I would cite. I hope my honourable friend will take an interest in this because this is the view of a highly neutral and highly respected academic, Professor J. B. Kelly, a distinguished historian specialising in British relations with the Middle East. In the English magazine Encounter of April 1980 he observed:

ANSWER.PARA: Soviet Russia is now in a stronger position than ever before in her history to accomplish her ambitions in the Middle East, whether they be to dominate the routes from Europe to the East, to command the landward and maritime approaches to the eastern Mediterranean, the Red Sea and the Gulf, or to lay hands upon the massive oil reserves of the region.

I happen to believe in every syllable that Professor Kelly has used. Again, that is a threat to the world. Every geo-political disturbance which flows from the stated ambition of the Soviet Union, the fact that the Soviet Union has moved so many fighter interceptors into the Far East, the fact that the Soviet Union is spending such vast sums of money-all these things represent a threat. The temptation-I know that it is difficult for some people to resist-is to seek to define a threat in clear, simple terms; to say: 'There is the only threat'. That is not the case.
This country must be prepared for a wide range of threats, varying in terms of reasonableness and seriousness. It was in that sense that Admiral Sir Anthony Synnot spoke.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this the good old Jim Killen of the fifties?

—I think the honourable member has a noogoora bur between his legs. I repeat, it was in that sense that Admiral Sir Anthony Synnot spoke. He was giving evidence to the Committee and explaining the complexity of seeking to find a single threat. There is no single threat for this country. We must be prepared to face a variety of contingencies and it is in precisely that sense that the Admiral spoke.

—The Minister for Foreign Affairs will recall stating in the House on 12 March that he would provide me with a copy of the written agreement between United States Secretary of State Haig and himself in relation to restrictions on the operational mode of B52 strategic bombers using Darwin air base. He is, of course, providing a copy of that document for my inspection today. Is it a fact that the document is expressed in exactly the terms used in the first full paragraph of column 1 on page 667 of Hansard of 11 March? Is it a fact that, with the exception of the heading-stating that these words would be the agreed form of expression by the Prime Minister to the House when speaking to the tabling of the relevant agreement-there is no other comment or notation and certainly no signature or signatures on it? In these circumstances, will he agree that the document has absolutely no standing in any respect at all? Therefore, how can the Government claim that the United States Government will inform it of any intent to carry nuclear weapons on B52s using Darwin, especially when the United States refuses to supply such information to allies who are at least equally as important as Australia, such as West Germany and Japan, and when Washington datelined newspaper reports, in the wake of this announcement on behalf of the United States State Department, repudiated any such obligation or intent to advise on the part of the United States Government? Finally, in short does he not agree that the document he referred to is worthless and that no other document exists, including the relevant agreement, stipulating explicitly and in a binding way that B52s will be unarmed, let alone requiring the disclosure of the carriage of nuclear armaments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated some time ago to the Leader of the Opposition, I have produced for his inspection the document referred to. There are no other documents. I gave the Leader of the Opposition that assurance.

ANSWER.PARA: He then asked whether the document had any standing. It has standing in this context: As the Leader of the Opposition well knows, the form of words finally agreed, as I made clear in this House some time ago, for use in the presentation of the agreement to this Parliament, was between the Secretary of State for the United States and me. If he believes a document made between representatives of government in that way has no standing, he does not have the same perception of government as I do. TALK.START.PARA: —I direct to the Minister for Primary Industry a question which I preface by pointing out to the Minister that the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union has claimed that the live sheep export trade is causing a loss of jobs in Australian meatworks and is calling for a ration of one live sheep for every sheep carcass exported. Is the Minister aware of claims now being made by the union that live sheep exports are having an adverse effect on the nation's wool clip? Is that in fact the case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The AMIEU has run a long campaign against live sheep exports. The basis of its claim in the first instance was that live sheep exports were affecting jobs for Australian workers in abattoirs and that, therefore, that trade should cease. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics conducted a study on the matter, as the House will know. The study demonstrated that in fact that was not the case and that, in the longer term, it might well be that jobs would be created by the continuance of the live sheep export trade. The fact of the matter is that there has been no diminution in requests from the Middle East for live sheep. I point out to the House that, despite the apparent presumption of the AMIEU, we cannot dictate to the Middle East what sort of sheep or sheep meats it buys. It has a preference for fresh-killed meat. The fact is that we are supplying only some 28 per cent of the live sheep trade to the Middle East, so obviously there are other markets from which the Middle East would draw if that trade were to cease. I point out that, whilst some 5.5 million head of live sheep have gone to the Middle East, at the same time some 4.2 million head of carcass equivalent have gone as well. So as well as the live sheep sales, there is a significant sale of sheep meats.

ANSWER.PARA: The AMIEU is drawing a long bow in its latest claim that the quality of the wool clip is affected by the fact that approximately 6 million wethers are going out of the country each year. I dispute that it is affecting the quality. It may well be affecting the composition of the flock and there may well be an increasing percentage of ewes in the total flock, but I dispute that it is affecting in any way the quality. The fact is that over the years there has been a change in the composition of the sheep flock of this country and the Australian wool grower has always met the demands placed upon him for the types of wool required by the world's wool users, so I think the AMIEU is drawing a very long bow on this issue.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members I present the third annual report of the Department of the House of Representatives. The report deals with activities of the Department in 1980 and refers to business and activities of the House itself. An important development within the Department in 1980 was the expansion of the existing familiarisation procedures for new members into a more detailed seminar program. Following the general elections last year, the seminar program was arranged by the Clerk of the House, with involvement by myself, the Deputy Speaker, the Whips and long-serving members of all parties, and officers from the parliamentary and Executive departments. Both new and existing members have expressed support for the concept. Seminars in future will be held before the first sitting of each new Parliament.

INTERJECT.PARA: A major feature of the 1980 parliamentary year was the selection of a designer for the new Parliament House, and approval by Parliament to proceed with preparation of a detailed design and with the site. The building program has now begun after an extensive planning period. Site work has almost reached the building level on the western side and the concept of the final positioning of the main structure is emerging.

Estimates committees operated again in 1980 under sessional orders amended to incorporate a number of suggestions for improving the working of the committees. Different opinions are held among members as to the role of Estimates committees and further modification of the sessional orders may be necessary when the committees are re-established in this Parliament. Legislation committees operated to a limited extent in 1980. Members of both sides of the House continue to assess these committees as a valuable addition to the legislative process. The sessional orders have been re-introduced in this Parliament with some minor amendment. By analysing its experience and adjusting where necessary, the House continues to refine its rules of procedure along the road of parliamentary reform.

I have previously stressed my commitment to parliamentary reform. I re-assert that commitment, and will continue to work, for example, towards the adoption of the Westminster convention relating to the Speaker, the televising of proceedings and a revision of our Standing Orders so that committees can perform the tasks we expect of them. The recent reforms of Parliament's procedures have not been great. The parliamentary institution has exhibited a resistance to change and the fact that there has been reform at all is a major advance. We must ensure that we continue to examine critically our own procedures and proposed avenues of parliamentary reform. We must implement revised practices where necessary. We must ensure that our procedures, or initial moves toward reform, are not allowed to atrophy.

The public is generally critical of the role of Parliament today. There is a continuing demand for Parliament's reform. The rising levels of education and sophistication among the public have led to greater expectations of the Parliament. We must ensure that we respond to these expectations, and mould a parliamentary institution which more effectively monitors the activities of modern day government. I commend this report to the House.

Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs for deliberately and persistently misleading the House in respect of the possible extension of SAMIN, the Statistical and Management Information Network, in the Commonwealth Employment Service, beyond Brisbane on a national basis.

Mr Speaker, in opening the debate on this censure motion against the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner), I ask you and members of the House to contrast some statements. The first statement is taken from the annual report of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs for 1979-80, tabled by the Minister in this House on 2 December 1980. The statement I quote without qualification from that document tabled by the Minister was in these terms:

SAMIN has been implemented in all CES offices in Brisbane using the Public Service Board's MANDATA facilities. An evaluation is being undertaken of the system in an operational environment before further implementation.

The statement that the extension of the Statistical and Management Information Network was contemplated and was waiting upon the outcome of an evaluation in Brisbane caused the members on this side of the House to put a number of questions to the Minister. Indeed, I asked one-third of such questions on 11 March this year. In answer to my question the Minister, speaking in this House, said the following words:

That was done initially on the basis that its continuing to be linked into Mandata would depend upon the decision to extend SAMIN nationally and on the capacity of Mandata, given the demands upon it by the Public Service Board and other departments, to fulfil the requirements of SAMIN.
He further said:

The position is still that an evaluation of the operation of SAMIN in Brisbane will be undertaken before any decision is made to extend it nationally. At that time a decision will have to be made as to whether the Mandata computer or some other computer will be used.

There we have two statements made by the Minister: One which appeared in the annual report was about the possible extension of SAMIN nationally, depending on the outcome of an evaluation. That report was tabled on 2 December last year. On 11 March the Minister said again that the position was still that an evaluation of SAMIN would be undertaken before any decision was made to extend it nationally, and at that time the decision would have to be made as to whether the Mandata computer or some other computer would be used. I ask honourable members to contrast those statements made by the Minister in December 1980 and March 1981 with these two statements: On 4 September 1980, during the hearing of Senate Estimates Committee B, an interchange occurred. The person being questioned was Mr MacDonald, Assistant Secretary of the Finance Branch of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. Senator Evans asked him:
How on earth did you chalk up a surplus in that area? Is it just obsolete equipment?
The answer given to that Estimates Committee was in these terms:

No, the machines were bought when we thought that we were expanding SAMIN, in 1979-80, into other States from Brisbane. As it turned out we cannot do that and we have had to dispose of the terminal printers.
That reply is quite unequivocal. On 4 September Mr MacDonald said:
As it turned out we cannot do that and we have had to dispose of the terminal printers.
Mr MacDonald was asked why he could not do that, and his answer was quite clear, concise and unequivocal. He said:
The Mandata computer has not sufficient computing capacity to allow us to expand Mandata beyond Brisbane.
He was asked further questions and he went on to say:

The Mandata system indicated to us that a certain amount of computing time would be available. This was agreed to some two years ago by the interdepartmental committee on ADP matters. The arrangement was that although the computer time would be offered to us under Mandata we would have to buy peripheral equipment to run our own system. In other words, we had to buy terminal printers. We proceeded to buy the equipment in 1979-80. Subsequent to the letting of contracts and purchase of equipment, the Mandata organisation advised us that in fact, because of its own requirements there was no longer sufficient capacity for us to expand SAMIN, our statistical collection system, beyond Brisbane.

I suggest to the House through you, Mr Speaker, that we could not have a clearer contradiction out of the mouth of one of the senior members of the Minister's Department. It was put on record before the Senate Estimates Committee in September of last year. That was before he tabled the report in the House on 2 December. He followed this up with three answers culminating in the one to which I have alluded which is in stark contradiction.

But in case that is not enough, in case someone would like in some way to wriggle around that stark contradiction, let me read to the House what is contained in a document from the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs concerning the revised estimates for 1980-81. This document would have had to have been before the Minister by the end of December 1980. It would have been to the Department of Finance in January of this year. What does this document say on this issue? Let me read it. The heading on the document is 'Revised Estimates 1980-81', the division is capital works and services, plant and equipment, Commonwealth Employment Service, computer equipment and the variation item under consideration amounts to $393,000. Under the heading 'Reason for variation' these words appear, which would have been considered by the Minister before the end of 1980:

The appropriation provided funds to cover the purchase and installation costs of 26 visual display units required in Queensland following the Department's decision not to extend SAMIN to other States.

That is the document that was before the Minister. It was considered by him at the end of 1980, following which he misled this House about the possibility of the extension of SAMIN, and possibly Mandata. He said that it all depended upon the outcome of an evaluation of what was going on in Brisbane. Let me repeat what was stated in this document that was considered before the end of last year. Under the heading 'Reason for variation' the document stated:

The appropriation provides funds to cover the purchase and installation costs of 26 visual display units required in Queensland following the Department's decision not to extend SAMIN to other States.

TALK.START.PARA: —He ought to resign.
—Of course he ought to resign. The document that was sighted and authorised by the Minister went on:

SPEECH.PARA: Following discussions between this Department, the Departments of Finance and Administrative Services and Information Electronics Ltd, it was decided that all the equipment should be purchased and all but 26 VDUs declared surplus requirements.

There you have it, Mr Speaker. The contrast is stark, clear and unequivocal. Against the statements that this Minister gave to the Parliament on three occasions in answer to questions following up what was contained in the document he tabled on 2 December last year, we have, in terms of what was said to the Senate Estimates committee in September 1980 and in a document considered by him before the end of 1980 and which went to the Department of Finance in January of this year, clear evidence of the Department's decision not to extend SAMIN to other States.

Mr Speaker, so that there be a clear understanding that what we are talking about here is not some peripheral minor issue, let me remind you, sir, and honourable members, of just how important is this thing SAMIN we are talking about because it may be regarded as something esoteric. I refer the House to the 1978-79 report of the National Director of the Commonwealth Employment Service tabled in the House in May last year. This is what is said about the importance of the SAMIN system. The report states:
During 1978-79 the design and development of a new statistical and management information network (SAMIN) was completed. The objectives of SAMIN are to:
produce statistics which are more useful for management purposes and the assessment of local and national labour market conditions;
provide a data information base which will aid the development and evaluation of programs and labour market studies;
rationalise the statistical burden on CES offices; and reduce the costs of collection; and
maintain and enhance the current statistical series.
The report continues:
The SAMIN system will operate on the Public Service Board's Mandata network which consists of a central computer facility in Canberra linked to small computers in each State capital.

In metropolitan and larger provincial centres CES offices will be equipped with visual display units and printers. This will allow each office to enter data directly into the SAMIN system and receive daily reports of applicant and vacancy transaction volume. In country offices data will be recorded manually and forwarded to the regional processing and control centres for input into the system.
The report concludes on this point:

Progressive implementation of the SAMIN system is planned with its introduction into Queensland late in 1979. Subsequently, SAMIN will be extended to all other States with the aim of having the system operating nationally by early 1981.

That is what we are talking about, a sophisticated basically important piece of computerised equipment which is asserted by the Department in its annual report tabled in this House as being essential to the more efficient discharge of these fundamental programs concerned with employment and unemployment and the matching of people registered for employment and vacancies. It is an absolutely fundamental matter. Then we pick up the statement of 2 December to which I have referred as to what will happen about the national extension of this program. In the report tabled at the end of the year the Minister said that the program would be extended depending upon the outcome of the evaluation. In answers to questions, into which I will now go in more detail, further statements were made misleading this House about the position in regard to the possible extension when in fact, as I have established, the decision was already clearly taken that that extension would not take place.

Having opened in that way, and in the limited time available to me, let me try to flesh out the details and background of this grotesque misleading of the House in regard to this fundamental matter. The statement to which I have referred was contained in the report which was tabled at the end of last year. A number of questions were asked. I have referred to the one that I finally asked. The first one was asked by the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) on 3 March. She referred to the statement in the annual report, and in reply the Minister said:
No steps have been taken to extend SAMIN beyond Brisbane. The function of SAMIN is still being evaluated against the background of experience in Brisbane.
A similar sort of answer was given to the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys) on 5 March, when he asked a question about this evaluation. The Minister said:
The evaluation is ongoing. I am not aware of a precise completion date for it. I will make inquiries of my Department and provide the honourable gentleman with an answer.
I believe this answer has now been provided.

Let us look at what emerged, how this situation has arisen and the circumstances in which the Minister found it necessary to mislead this House. In the latter part of 1979 difficulties became apparent in regard to this system on which work had commenced in 1976. By the end of 1980, approximately $3m had been expended upon the work of investigation and the initial implementation of this system in Brisbane. By the end of 1979 difficulties were becoming apparent and, in the result, through the period January to April 1980 discussions took place between the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, the Public Service Board, and computer consultants, Burroughs Ltd, regarding the problems of the operation of SAMIN and the Mandata network. Those discussions resulted in the appointment, on 3 April last year, of Burroughs as official consultants to the Department to deal with the problems concerning the operation of SAMIN in relation to the availability of time on the Mandata system.

Even then we see the beginning of the weaving of this fabric of deceit. The day before, on 2 April, the Minister had given a misleading answer to the honourable member for Griffith, who had asked a question on that occasion. Because of time limitations I cannot go into that. I simply say that that is when the pattern of misleading started.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wasn't he telling the truth?

—No, he was not telling the truth, as he obviously was not telling the truth on those occasions to which I have had the time to allude. Let us see what followed. Mr Speaker, I apologise that I have to do this very quickly. TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to debate this matter, which was set down on the Notice Paper during the last sitting week of this Parliament. Having regard to the tone of his speech and his actions in the House, I might say that those assertions were rather hysterically made. The honourable member for Wills alleged on a number of occasions that I misled the Parliament on the future development of the Statistical and Management Information Network, SAMIN-not a fish to be played with but something to be seriously considered. It is the Statistical and Management Information System currently operating in the Brisbane offices of the Commonwealth Employment Service. The honourable gentleman suggested that a decision had been taken that SAMIN would not be extended to operate on a national basis. I will quote directly from a question asked by the honourable gentleman on 11 March this year. He asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it a fact that a decision was taken by the Minister's Department prior to September last year--
I stress this-
to abandon the planned introduction of the Statistical and Management Information Network on a national basis . . .

The answer to that question is clearly no. No decision has been made to abandon SAMIN on a national basis. It is the usual practice of the Opposition to attempt to besmirch the reputation of Ministers with wild and unfounded allegations. I acknowledge that that is part of the game of politics. We deal with such things in the House not every day but as they come along. However, in this case the allegations made by the honourable gentleman reflect on the competence and integrity of officers of my Department. I take such allegations very seriously. The honourable gentleman has challenged statements in the annual report of my Department for the year 1979-80. That is an attack upon the integrity and honesty of officers of my Department.

I say that because SAMIN is a system designed to aid departmental management. Explanations of its development have been given to committees of Parliament and to the public. These explanations have been based on the understanding that SAMIN would go national after an evaluation. It has always been thus and it still is the case.

By way of background, SAMIN was introduced in Brisbane as a system to keep the management of the CES better informed of the volume and nature of transactions conducted by its officers. Although a system of this kind had been considered for some time, the discovery that the Public Service Board's Mandata system at that time had spare automatic data processing capacity led to SAMIN's development. SAMIN was introduced in September 1979 in Brisbane to test its efficacy and efficiency. At that time Mandata was developing. At a point where SAMIN was reasonably well developed in Brisbane, early last year, consultants-the consultants to which the honourable gentleman referred, Burroughs Ltd-were hired by the Department to assess the system and the scope for its further development.

Those consultant's reports which were available to the Department in mid-1980 led to the Department taking the view that Mandata would not continue to have the spare capacity, the basis on which SAMIN was originally implemented, to allow SAMIN to be operated nationally on that equipment. If at that time SAMIN was to be extended nationally, it would have been necessary to obtain additional central ADP equipment. In other words, it would have been necessary to upgrade Mandata equipment. The estimated cost was about $1.7m. The Department decided not to seek additional ADP equipment as its own proposals for acquiring that equipment for the Commonwealth Employment Service, the Job Bank system, of which public notice has been given, were already well advanced. I was informed of the Department's decision in early July 1980 and I endorsed a course of action which is well summarised in an information bulletin of September 1980 of the National Director of the Commonwealth Employment Service. That bulletin, dated 8 September 1980, was circulated to CES staff members throughout Australia. I will quote from one passage of the bulletin which dealt with CES computerisation and described what was happening regarding Job Bank. It pointed out that SAMIN had by then been implemented successfully in all Brisbane offices and, after initial teething problems, was operating reliably. It stated:

Consequently, SAMIN could only be extended beyond Brisbane by upgrading MANDATA's computer or acquiring other computing resources.
I draw the attention of the House to that passage particularly in relation to the passage at the end of the answer I gave on 11 March 1981. I stated:
At that time-
Namely, after an evaluation was to be completed-
a decision will have to be made as to whether the Mandata computer or some other computer will be used.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is greatly concerned at the likelihood of a further round of interest rate increases of the order of one per cent or so. We are so concerned because of a decision made by the Government yesterday evening in which it announced an increase in the Australian savings bonds interest rate from 11 1/2 per cent to 12 1/4 per cent, a rise of three-quarters of a per cent. The savings bonds rate traditionally has been closely associated with the building society rates. When there has been movement in the savings bond rate it has been normal for there to be an increase in the building society rate, if the savings bond rate movement was upward, and with the increase in deposit rates by building societies inevitably there has been an increase in their loan rates and therefore higher loan repayments for home buyers purchasing their homes through building society loans. SPEECH.PARA: Now we have the situation where the banks can also attempt to keep pace with savings bond increases by increasing their rates on deposits without having to depend on the Government to approve increases in those rates. Of course, there is a limitation in the sense that there is still control on the lending rate so that the extent to which the banks can increase their deposit rates is limited to some extent by that fact.
