SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard an interim report, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) described it, covering his five months in office. He has paid considerable attention to the fact that we now define ourselves a middle power. In fact, some eight pages of the speech is devoted to defining a middle power. He has also raised the question of Australia being an actor on the world stage. The problem with that sort of reference, of course, is that actors often fail. Their words might be effective, but their performance might be very limited indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the most significant part of what the Minister has said is that we have our own national interests to look after, and that we have considerable weight in South East Asia. Having highlighted those words, I want to make the point in my submission that the Government has not acted in accordance with its words. It was about page 14 of the speech before the Minister referred to the new Reagan Administration. I want to deal with it from the beginning.

The Foreign Minister spoke of the policies of the Reagan Administration. He does not seem to understand that our ally has a vastly different set of policies now from what it had four months ago. These drastic changes in the way that Washington sees the world have the most serious implications for Australia. It is amazing to note that, as the Minister has now said, there is broad agreement between the Australian Government and the Reagan Administration on the analysis and the evaluation of international affairs. There was apparently broad agreement between this Government and the Carter Administration a mere five months ago. The inevitable conclusion is that since American policies have changed so drastically in the short intervening period we do not have an independent foreign policy but an imitative and subservient one. A deadly serious choice is facing us. Will we use our influence to counsel moderation, to urge a new search for easing international tensions-detente or the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty was not mentioned in any part of the Minister's speech-or will we, as this Government is doing, take actions and enter into agreements which will encourage increased mistrust between the super-powers and trigger a new and criminally expensive arms race ultimately operating against our interests by increasing instability in this region of the world? It is becoming apparent that if a major international disaster is to be averted middle powers such as Australia must play an increasingly important role. Australia's importance has increased substantially in the past five years largely because of its resources. It will increase even more in the next decade.

The American alliance is important, but it is not, and cannot be, a substitute or an excuse for a vigorous policy of independently assessing our own interests. Super-powers such as the United States and the Soviet Union tend to export instability and resolve their conflicting interests in places remote from their own territories; for example, in Africa, the Middle East, the Gulf, and in South East Asia. We are still living with the very real problems of Vietnam and Kampuchea. Kampuchea was the first matter mentioned by the Minister. Those problems still affect the United States but pose more ominous problems for the countries of this region, not the least of which is Australia.

The United States, like every great power, will put its interests first. Anyone who thinks otherwise has a simplistic and naive view of the international arena. It is we who must worry most about the stability of our region. The easy answer-to leave our powerful ally to call the strategic shots-unfortunately is clearly the wrong answer.

We already have a number of United States bases in Australia, a subject which I will canvass at some later time. We are contributing substantially to the ANZUS alliance. Do we really believe that the staging of nuclear weapons throughout Australia, the contingency against which the B52 agreement has been entered into, will contribute to stability in our part of the world? It will not. If anything, it will encourage the Soviet Union to escalate its involvement with Vietnam to counter that perceived threat. It will decrease respect among our regional neighbours for our independence of judgment and, consequently, it will lessen the respect with which our voice is heard in regional councils. It will be a major contribution to escalating a new cold war between the super-powers and in our region provoking increased instability.

When I commenced my speech I said that United States policies have fundamentally changed. The Minister for Foreign Affairs should realise that the United States strategic world view has fundamentally changed. For the past four months we have witnessed the most dramatic changes in American attitudes, not only in the rhetoric of General Haig but also in the American activities around the world. There emerges a clear pattern: Intervention in El Salvador to prop up a government which, according to the testimony of the United States Ambassador, an experienced and professional man, had slaughtered thousands of its own people; increased armaments and military assistance to the Middle East and to the Gulf; an amount of $600m committed in additional arms supplies to Saudi Arabia; additional military aid for Egypt and Israel; a mooted decision to supply arms directly to Afghanistan; increased support for South Africa and its repugnant policies; the establishment of new American bases and the enlargement of old ones in the Horn of Africa, in the Gulf and in the Indian Ocean; dramatically increased support for the military dictatorships and juntas of Latin America; a return to the Cold War rhetoric of the 1950s in relation to the Soviet Union; and, finally, the establishment of staging facilities for long range strategic nuclear bombers in Australia.

All these events make it absolutely clear that the United States is determined to increase its power in every region of the world. But are these increases in Australia's interests? Perhaps it would be comforting to believe that the United States fights for peace, justice and human rights and that the Soviet Union is an unprincipled aggressor. That the latter is true in the case of Afghanistan unfortunately does not make the former proposition tenable. We have witnessed in Washington unprincipled and transparent policy reversals which scrap human rights as an instrument of foreign policy and substitute supposedly an all-out attack on terrorism. The problem we face is that General Haig includes amongst those he calls 'terrorists' patriots who oppose dictatorial governments-governments that the United States supports because they further its own interests and strategic designs. Let me be more specific. Washington supports dictatorships or military juntas in South Korea, Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia and a score of other countries. It is providing them with increased military assistance and weapons which will be used to crush any dissident opinion, or those who attempt to establish a democracy. But Washington encourages or is about to encourage terrorist activities against such internationally recognised governments as that of Angola because that Government is socialist or Marxist or perhaps just because it is not in an American alliance.

The Australian Labor Party has never held and will not hold any brief for the Soviet Union. We deplore its abuses of human rights and its invasion of weaker countries. We equally deplore any simple-minded attachment to the United States as the paragon of virtue. Our foreign policy has to be based on a realistic appraisal of the faults of both countries and on a willingness to break ranks with the United States when it acts in a way which fosters instability in Asia and the Pacific. The Foreign Minister has implied quite clearly that we should trust Washington. But we must learn from the lessons of recent history how governments in Washington behave, how they pursue their own interests, and how they have made tragic mistakes. It is quite wrong for us to be always following the United States ship, no matter who its captain is or what course it takes. Will the Americans really come to our aid in the time of a crunch?

I wish to place this matter in perspective. In the early 1960s the then Australian Foreign Minister, Mr Barwick, returned from Washington and announced that the United States would support us if we were attacked by the Indonesians. Those were the days of confrontation between Indonesia and Malaysia. Subsequently, it emerged that Mr Barwick had received a secret assurance to this effect from the American Secretary of State, Dean Rusk-a secret assurance which was lodged in the safe in the Embassy in Washington. Some time later President Kennedy became aware of the agreement and he countermanded his Secretary of State and made it clear that the Americans would not feel bound by the ANZUS Treaty to come to our aid in such an event.

This incident gives cause for a long and careful pause because the ANZUS alliance does not commit anybody to active involvement in anything other than through consultation. Perhaps we should reflect also upon the fact that when President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger decided to bomb Cambodia they did not even inform their own Cabinet. Is it any wonder that the American people so revolted against those people who so deceived their own nation that they were thrown out of office? Their policies operated throughout South East Asia and certainly brought about the undoing of Sihanouk in Kampuchea. The Foreign Minister is naive, and dangerously so, if he is asking this Parliament to base our foreign policy on implicitly trusting the American leaders as they change from time to time.

Within the last few weeks Washington has offered $15 billion in additional weapons and military aid to Latin America, Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia. The tremendous danger is that the new Administration in Washington is attempting to impose military solutions on every type of regional problem. United States defence spending next year will be 30 per cent of Federal spending. We have to look at what is happening in the United States. Is not the best defence the welfare of one's own people? In its same Budget the United States has slashed the concessions to the victims of black lung disease-the miners, by $378m. That is where there is a lack of balance and understanding. One can well lose the defence of one's country by a malaise from within. We want to be able to say to new Administrations in the United States: 'Do not forsake diplomacy. Do not forswear subtlety for a simplistic and militaristic approach'. The present policies of the United States smack of not only excessive simplicity but also ill-considered haste. We are concurring instead of vigorously urging policies which will not create further instability in our part of the world. But the West Germans did not do that. Last week the West German Foreign Minister urged General Haig not to become so obsessed with the military build up that he neglected arms control. We have not made any such representations and we should do so.

We are in the process of becoming a major power in South East Asia-we already are a major power in the South Pacific-but we have not taken any initiatives commensurate with our status and regional responsibilities. No one pretends that the problems in Vietnam and Kampuchea have easy solutions. But if we moved to re-establish our program of aid to Vietnam we would have some influence and capacity for initiative in that area. In order to retain our capacity for initiative we must preserve a substantial degree of independence. If we lock ourselves in completely with the United States of America strategic view of the world-if we become, as we are in danger of becoming, a South Pacific outpost for Washington-we cannot expect to be taken seriously by our regional neighbours. It is about time we formulated our own strategic view and acted accordingly.

In the Middle East the United States Government has now promised another $600m in armaments for Saudi Arabia. Naturally, that worries Tel Aviv, so another $600m in military aid is given to Israel. That, in turn, worries Sadat in Egypt, so another $1.65 billion in 'security assistance' is given to Egypt. What a recipe for regional instability! General Haig has even indicated that he plans to over-arm Israel to deter future adventures by Libya, Syria or other radical Arabs. Is that not a recipe for disaster? No doubt the American economy will improve as the world's biggest arms factories gear up to full international conflict level. Given the way in which Washington works and the power of the armaments lobby there, we develop a healthy cynicism about current United States policy. One of President Reagan's aides admitted this last week:
So far the perception we've created is one of willy-nilly shovelling arms all over the world.
How true, but how tragic. The Minister in his speech referred to this belief of the Reagan Administration:
. . . that the various elements of foreign policy-economic matters, human rights, strategic and political questions . . . must all be seen as components of the whole.
He continued:
There are precious few human rights in the Soviet Union and Cuba, and in the regimes they support and install.

We could say: 'True, but what about China, South America and a number of other areas'. His summary would have been much more impressive and balanced had he pointed out that there are precious few human rights under most of the regimes which the United States supports-as I said, particularly those in Latin America and Asia. A close examination of the report of the Human Rights Commission in Geneva will reveal that of the many countries which systematically practise torture, the majority are supported by the new American Administration.

The fact is that the military dictatorship has become the dominant form of government in those sectors of the Third World which are geographically and politically closest to the United States. It cannot last. Why is it that a government has to get arms to suppress its people? How can that possibly last when the only solution for those people is to turn to communism and revolution, which has always been the solution, without any regard for human rights and democratic rights? It is most disturbing that the Minister said:
It has to be recognised that in some important respects this year is not propitious for the North-South dialogue.
We hear that from the wealthy countries every year. No year will ever be propitious. Meanwhile, millions of people will starve.

The Australian Labor Party has always had policies which relate to humanity and human rights. Ours is a party of concern. This Government should not delay any longer making a generous response to the needs of the poorest countries. This Government's performance in providing assistance to the developing world is now at the lowest level it has ever been. This Government is not moving towards meeting the assistance target of 0.7 per cent of gross national product set by the United Nations; it is moving away from it. Its allocation is now down to 0.4 per cent of GNP. The level was highest under the Labor Government. I agree with the Minister in his statement that it is essential that:
. . . the conduct of Australia's foreign policy at the professional level be of a high standard.

But what are the facts? I believe our professional officers are doing their best, but the Government's policies in those areas have led to more than 50 of our career officers recently resigning or transferring. That is a development which has weakened our ability even to conduct a foreign policy of a high standard. Perhaps for the most glaring example of this weakness we should return to the situation in Washington. In spite of the fact that we have there a number of diplomatic officers, and 200 representatives of the Department of Defence and of the armed Services, there is not one person reporting, on a regular basis, changes in the strategic policies of our American allies. It is those policies that determine whether we get involved in a war, yet we have nobody there reporting from that very source.

The Foreign Minister devoted a substantial part of his speech to the issue of Kampuchea. I have been to the Kampuchea border. I have also been to Vietnam and to Thailand and I have been in the camps catering for the unfortunate refugees. What I want to say now is based on that sort of knowledge. There are glaring omissions in the Minister's analysis. He does not recognise the issues at the heart of the Kampuchean problem, namely, firstly, the attempts by the Pol Pot regime between 1975 and 1978 to destroy its own people; and secondly, the rescue of the survivors of the Khmer people by Vietnam. The Minister described the Pol Pot regime as morally repugnant. That is mild language indeed for a regime which, in a genocidal fury, slaughtered or starved to death more than three million of its own people. I invite the Minister to go to the refugee camps of the Khmers and ask them who they fear the most. He will find that it is Pol Pot. The Minister did not spell out the horrifying statistics of the Kampuchean tragedy. Further, he made no apology for the continued recognition of the Pol Pot regime long after it had been driven from power and long after its massive crimes had been revealed to a shocked world. The Minister claimed that the balance of arguments for derecognition of Pol Pot was not clear cut. How much more appalling does international behaviour have to be to make a recognition issue clear cut?

Again, the Minister said that the Government's opposition to Vietnam's invasion of Kampuchea was implacable. That is a strong word. It is unqualified by any recognition that the intervention of Vietnam saved the survivors of the Kampuchean people. Is Vietnam to get no credit or even recognition of that fact? Further, the Minister rejected any suggestion-and it was not one made by Labor-that the Heng Samrin Administration represented the Khmer people. The Heng Samrin Administration has struggled to get Kampuchea back on the road to recovery. It gets no credit from the Minister yet his Government recognised as the legitimate representative of the Khmer people an exiled junta of genocidal fanatics. This points up the contradiction in the Minister's speech and it makes his analysis pitiful indeed.

Having finally steeled itself to withdraw Australian diplomatic support from the Pol Pot regime, the Government has taken no steps towards a settlement, towards a solution in Indo China. Of course, Labor has long advocated derecognition. What the Government has followed is Labor's policy, and I suggest that it now follow another Labor policy. Labor advocates an independent Australian initiative. We should aim as our highest diplomatic priority in Asia to arrange a regional conference on the Indo-China issue as a forerunner of a larger conference which would have to include the United States, the Soviet Union and China. Australia should strive to play the part of the honest broker in this issue. That is not beyond the capacity of a middle power as the Minister correctly describes Australia. Accordingly, we should be setting about persuading the Association of South East Asian Nations states and Vietnam to confer on the Kampuchean issue. Such a conference could aim at the withdrawal of the Vietnamese, linked to cast iron guarantees that the Pol Pot forces would also be disarmed and prevented from rushing back into the vacuum created. The conference should aim also at a genuine act of self-determination within Kampuchea.

The Minister mentioned the possibility of a Third Force emerging in the affairs of Kampuchea. But the history of Indo-china since 1945 shows that the Third Force idea is mainly wishful thinking. It failed in Vietnam and in Laos. In Kampuchea itself the United States destroyed the neutrality of Kampuchea under Prince Sihanouk. The Minister rightly pointed to the risk of international isolation of Vietnam but he suggested nothing to prevent it. Australia itself is at fault in helping to force Vietnam into isolation. Our petty and thoughtless action in cutting off our aid to Vietnam in 1979 is not, of course, to be compared with the ruthless breaking of United States promises of post-war aid to Vietnam.

Overall, the Minister's remarks on Kampuchea are marked by double standards and a lack of compassion. In the case of Vietnam, we can detect the lingering animosity of a member of a party which saw its policies on Vietnam totally discredited, totally defeated, totally humiliated, and which towards the end of that war, helped lead his party to political defeat. The offensive in Vietnam was to stop the downward thrust of China, the new found ally of this Government. That is the point. This Government bears towards Vietnam an obvious animosity, but rancour is no basis for foreign policy.

Not one Minister of this Government has ever visited Hanoi. A lame duck ambassador is in Hanoi because of the Government's attitude towards Vietnam. The Government ought to remember that people are entitled to aid. If there is another thrust by China against Vietnam, Australia will receive millions of refugees. Where is the substance of the Government's policy in that event? Where is the influence that will stop that happening? It will not be solved by B52 bombers because the Government has already dealt with them. We have to make it clear that Vietnam is the most important power in South East Asia. Our neighbours in ASEAN will agree with that. What is the Government's policy? It is so short-sighted and so mean-spirited that it is contrary to Australia's best interests. The Australian people will remember that the parties which comprise this Government took a generation to recognise the realities of China-indeed, to recognise it at all. Fortunately, our national interests will not have to wait that long again to be properly protected by realistic and constructive policies towards Vietnam. The next Labor government will treat relations with Vietnam with the importance and urgency they deserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be a long time off.

—It will not be a long time off because the issues are very close to our shores. If the Government thinks it can solve the problems by pitting bombers against flesh and blood it is gravely mistaken. The Vietnamese fought for 30 years against the French and everybody else, and the Government ought to realise that. Specifically, the Minister's speech raised the prospect of Australia, as a middle power, having an independent foreign policy but it did not follow through with any initiatives. It is on that basis that I make the point that it is about time Australia developed independent foreign policies which will bring peace and stability into the South East Asian region. It has to exercise its own initiative. It should not leave it to somebody else.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has to pursue initiatives that are in accordance with Australia's interests and Australian public opinion. By so doing we will become a better ally to the United States. We will lessen the burden that the Haigs and others want to impose on the American people by the stupid suggestion that the way to peace is through war and that the way to detente is through an escalation of arms. It is a fallacy. It will not work. The American people will reject it before long. It is about time a government in this region stood up and stated: 'We are an ally but because we live in this region we have views which are much more fundamentally orientated to the truth and to the valid claims of the region than those of any high-powered general or somebody who espouses the cause of democracy in the world when it is failing so fast'. What a tragedy it is that all the wars fought in South Korea or Vietnam have done nothing but bring about dictatorships and communism. They have failed at every level. If people are not granted human rights and a chance to develop their capacity to run their own countries totalitarian regimes are created.

It is about time General Haig and others started talking again, as Carter did, about human rights and democracy and about giving aid when promised. Honourable members opposite should not groan. They are young enough to have been involved in those conflicts. What about the 450 Australian dead left in Vietnam? The Government should face up to these issues, as have the Australian people. The Government was hounded out of office because of its failure in this area. Today we heard a speech that still puts us in the position of regarding Vietnam as the enemy. That can be a danger, as I have said, if there is a war between China and Vietnam. It is our clear-cut responsibility as a nation in this region to get Vietnam and ASEAN together to talk about Vietnam's withdrawal from Kampuchea once Pol Pot and his regime are disarmed. Those talks should not be held on any other level. Until such time as we organise that conference-we should be initiating it-we will have nothing but instability in this region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) on the survey of Australia's foreign relations which he presented to the Parliament today. Of particular significance is his assessment of the new Reagan Administration in the United States. He said that the philosophical perspectives and the analysis of the international situation of that new Administration are similar to the policies of the Australian Government over a longer period. That is a very significant statement and I will bring it to the attention of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) later. We in Australia have to decide where we stand. Are we a member of the Western alliance or are we not? We have to accept obligations and responsibilities as a member of that alliance. We have to accept those obligations and responsibilities also under the ANZUS treaty. The Australian Labor Party cannot pretend to have a bipartisan approach to the ANZUS treaty and the United States without accepting that it brings responsibilities and obligations with it. All that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has done today is to criticise the agreement that the Government has with the United States concerning the B52 bombers, which will be unarmed and carry no bombs.
—What did he say about the Soviet Union?

—I will deal with that in a minute. He said nothing about the Soviet Union. I come back to the matter at hand; that is, the Opposition is speaking with a forked tongue. Of course, our relations with the United States have to be two-sided. They have to be based on a mutual respect of differing views, with neither party being subservient to the other. I believe the United States would not necessarily defend Australia in all circumstances. That is why I regard the ANZUS treaty as important. That is why I believe we have to work at our relationship with the United States towards establishing areas where our national interests coincide. There will be occasions when they do not coincide. Obviously there will be times when there will be differences between the United States and Australia. That is only right and proper and to be expected.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the question of El Salvador. The current instability and uncertainty in El Salvador have provided a dilemma for the United States. The Minister said this afternoon that human rights are of great importance. But President Reagan has had difficult decisions to make. In the Minister's terms, he has had to weigh up the strategic and political questions, economic matters and human rights issues. The United States has seen at its front door the threat of the Soviet surrogate Cuba exploiting instability and the United States has had to take the strategic decision to supply equipment and advisers. That needs to be understood by allies of the United States, and particularly by the Opposition. The Soviet-backed Cubans are fostering and further fomenting subversion and instability in Central America. I think the analogy is the Kennedy blockade of Cuba. The United States, faced with a virtual Soviet presence on its front door, has had to act to protect--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen to members of the Opposition scream when one talks about the United States. The United States has had to act to protect its strategic interests; and that needs to be understood. Nobody on this side of the House wants another Vietnam-type war. Nobody on this side of the House wants any type of war. But let the Soviets back off. Let the Cubans back off. Let them stop supplying advisers and arms. As Senator Wheeldon, a member of the Australian Labor Party, has said in the Senate, as long as Cuban advisers are present in El Salvador, the United States obviously has the right to provide its advisers. The alternative is a Cuban-backed regime. Does the Opposition in this place want a Cuban-backed regime in El Salvador? Let it tell us that. I believe it does, but let it tell the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Soviets must be laughing because they know that reactions of the type shown by the Opposition will be used by propagandists. They will further be used to exploit and to foster the propaganda war to hide the real issue of the Soviet Union's surrogates and of its expansion in Central America.

I turn, as I said I would, to what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said. I think it was the most disappointing speech that I have heard him make in this Parliament. It was, I think, written for him by the left wing of the party. It shows me that perhaps there is about to be some sort of leadership struggle or power play in the Australian Labor Party with the Left being on top at present. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that Australia was to be an actor on the world stage. He said that this Government has not acted. Of course this Government has acted. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that there was no apparent difference in our policies today from those of four months ago.

I point out to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition the words that I referred to earlier, the words of the Foreign Minister, who is in the House at present. Whilst we agreed with certain Carter initiatives opposite the Soviet Union and particularly the reaction to the Soviet build-up in the Indian Ocean, there is now a new philosophical perspective and a new analysis of the international situation by the Reagan Administration. That is the difference. Obviously there were policy points on which the Australian Government agreed with the Carter Administration. Now we have an administration in the United States which has a philosophical perspective similar to the perspective of this Government, a perspective which this Government has had for a lot longer than the United States has had it.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition criticised the Minister for referring only to the United States on page 14 of his address. However, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition went on to spend most of his time attacking the Minister for what the Minister did say. Then the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I think, committed his most irresponsible act today. He said that we were supporting the staging of nuclear weapons in Australia by the United States. That is not true. That is a fabrication. I ask the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to withdraw that statement because that is an attempt to lead the people of Australia astray, to misinform the people of Australia. I assume that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, by saying that the present Government is supporting the staging of nuclear weapons by the United States and Australia, is trying to confuse members of the Australian public and to deliberately mislead them. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Foreign Minister have said that the B52 bombers that will call at and use the facilities at Darwin and will fly over the Cape York Peninsula will be unarmed and will carry no bombs. The Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister have said that, yet the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has the gall to get up in this House today to tell the House and the people of Australia that Australia is being used as a staging post for the use of nuclear weapons. That is terribly irresponsible and is a misleading of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —And wrong.

—I thank the honourable member. I accept the interjection of the honourable member for Diamond Valley. I have dealt with the question of El Salvador. Of course, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition attacked United States policy there. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition talked about dictatorships throughout the world. He talked about South Korea. He did not mention any Soviet-backed country.
—Or the Soviet itself.

—As the honourable member for Perth said, he did not talk of the Soviet itself. He did not talk about East Germany. He did not tell us of the Vietnamese invasion of Laos. That seems to be comfortably forgotten.
—Or Afghanistan.
—No other mention was made. The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), who is at the table, mentioned Afghanistan. That was completely ignored today by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.
—Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland.

—The countries of Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland were not mentioned today by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. All he said about the Soviet Union was that he deplored the Soviet attitude to human rights. Then he said that the United States was not a paragon of virtue; there are faults on both sides. I take it from that statement that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was advocating neutrality, advocating a neutral foreign policy for Australia. That is what I believe the Opposition stands for. What does that mean? That means that we do not know where we stand. The Minister for Foreign Affairs said that the lessons of history are that uncertainty, vacillation, disunity and weakness increase the prospect of war by inviting expansionist, aggressive behaviour by states seeking to change the balance of power to their own advantage. That statement by the Minister is, I think, one of the most profound statements on foreign policy matters made in this Parliament. It needs to be restated time and again. He has stated the lessons of history; that the weak are walked over in this world. I think that somebody once said that power speaks through the barrel of a gun. The United States is not aiming to invade anybody; it is responding to the build-up throughout the world of the Soviet Union. We did not hear from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition about the Soviet build-up in the Indian Ocean. He said that we should give more aid to Kampuchea. The Government has a very creditable record of giving aid to Kampuchea. I believe that the Deputy Leader rejected the total United States presence in the region. I take it that he supports the Soviet build-up in the Indian Ocean.
—Whose side is he on?

—I believe that the honourable member is on the side of the Soviet Union and his speech today clearly shows that. Furthermore his speech shows that he is an apologist for Vietnamese aggression in South East Asia.
—Don't you realise that kicking the commie can went out of fashion years ago?

—I realise that the Soviets have invaded Afghanistan. I realise that the Soviet Union is using Vietnamese facilities at Cam Ranh Bay and that the Soviet Indian Ocean fleet, built up in the Indian Ocean long before the United States responded, is changing at Cam Ranh Bay. I realise that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has communication facilities in Vietnam and now has a port 2,000 miles south of Vladivostock. That is what I realise the Soviets are doing. The Soviets have built up in the Indian Ocean. This build-up took place, I think from recollection in 1979 and started long before any United States build up. We have heard no talk about that today.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very disappointed with the interjection of the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown). Whilst he is having troubles with Parramatta Park, I know that he should realise that the Soviets are in Afghanistan. The Vietnamese are in Laos and Kampuchea and are being backed financially by the Soviet Union while it has the use of the facilities I just talked about for shipping, aircraft and communications. The honourable member ought to know that. The Opposition ought to face up to the fact that the Vietnamese are a threat in South East Asia. They have the largest standing army in South East Asia. They already occupy two countries and represent a direct threat to Thailand and Malaysia. The Vietnamese have made border incursions into Thailand in order to put fear into the people of that country. Vietnam has a larger standing force than the combined forces of the countries I have referred to. Those are the facts of the matter. Why did we not hear the Deputy Leader of the Opposition tell us about that today? We have to assume that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is an apologist for the Soviet Union and its aggression throughout the world.

In the time remaining, I will switch to a discussion of Australia's role as a middle power. I thought that the Minister's statement was an interesting intellectual analysis and one of the best we have heard for some time. I wish to talk of two matters arising from my own experience where Australia has played a small role but a role as a middle power. The first concerns the United Nations where the former member for Wills, the Hon. Gordon Bryant, and myself were present as parliamentary delegates. Together with delegates from other countries, we formed a parliamentarians group at the United Nations. This still functions and has full interpretor services and is part of General Assembly sessions. People from the Third World said to us: 'You as Australians can do that but if one of the superpowers had done it we would not have come along'. That proved to me that Australia has a middle power role. It showed that we are respected throughout the world as a middle power and that we can come with clean hands to a discussion of many issues.

The other point concerns the presence of the Royal Australian Air Force at Butterworth in Malaysia where I was briefly last week. The Australian presence acts as a bridge between Malaysia on the one hand and Singapore on the other. We contribute to the five-power defence arrangements. In fact, we are playing an important role that needs to be understood in that region of the world. I believe that our efforts there are appreciated. I do not believe for instance that it is well known that we are helping the Singaporeans to train in Australia members of their army and air forces. That is something that I would encourage. We heard nothing about that from the Opposition today. I congratulate those members of the Royal Australian Air Force who are doing a great job both as ambassadors and in helping the Malaysians and the Singaporeans. My final point concerns Australia and its role in the Commonwealth. The Minister spoke of the effective role that Australia, as a middle power, played in the Zimbabwe solution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of points on the speech of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) before passing to the remarks of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street). Firstly, the honourable member disputed the view expressed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) that Australia is now a staging point for the deployment of American nuclear weapons. I do not see why we have to keep disputing this; we indisputably are. Most of the American warships which visit my home town and home port of Fremantle carry nuclear weapons. The agreement which was entered by the Government on the use by B52s of Australian bases does not preclude the possibility that at some point in time B52s passing through Australia might well be armed with nuclear weapons. We have at North West Cape a facility which is responsible for transmitting fire orders to American ballistic missile submarines. All these facts are well known and well documented from American official sources. Some are attested to by the Government itself. We need a far more mature approach than has been displayed by the honourable member to the problems that we confront in our relationship with the American strategic nuclear deterrent.

SPEECH.PARA: My second point concerns Vietnam. From 1975 onwards the Opposition made persistent pleas to this Government that if it did not take seriously the moral obligations imposed upon it to provide assistance for the reconstruction of Vietnam that country would be forced to fall back upon the Soviet Union. We pointed to the difficulties that would occur because of the pressures that would be placed upon the Vietnamese administration by the Soviet Union to allow it the use of the Cam Ranh Bay facilities, with the Vietnamese being forced to succumb if they were not provided with the sorts of material assistance they required for economic recovery. We have persistently warned the Government about that and have said that such steps would be against Australia's interests. We have persistently attempted to get the Government to do something about it. Just as persistently, the Government has done nothing. It is now reaping the consequences of not using the pressure that Australia could undoubtedly place on the United States, or the friendly influence or persuasion in which it could indulge with that country, to persuade it to adopt a similar policy. We are now confronted by the consequences of that failure.

The Minister's statement is extremely general, but follows a visit by him to the United States during which agreements of a specific military nature were entered into. Such discussions must have been based on quite specific understandings about the nature of future directions of American policy and our views on our association with it. Yet none of that appears in this statement-at least not specifically associated with the agreements into which Australia entered. The Minister has dealt with the question of the distribution of power in north-east Asia without giving us the benefit of the Government's views on disputes within the new American Administration on a one-China policy or a two-Chinas policy which, despite former President Ford's visit to China, have not been resolved. Did the Minister express to the United States a view on proposed arms sales to Taiwan? If not, why not? If so, what did he say; why did he not present the details to the Parliament in the course of his rather lengthy analysis of our relationship with China?

The Minister visited the United States at a time when President Reagan had signalled a shift in United States policy towards South Africa, one potentially of considerable embarrassment to our Government; yet he has given no indication that he exchanged opinions on the matter with the officials he met. The Minister spoke of a commitment to American objectives in the Indian Ocean, without expressing views on whether features of the burgeoning military involvement of the United States in that area, and the massive arms sales to such states as Saudi Arabia, are appropriate means of responding to the problems that we confront in that region. An unexceptionable analysis of the requirements of a middle power such as Australia's to assume an appropriate role in world affairs was followed by apparently unrelated, but unequivocal applause for the direction of the policy of our major ally. This does not really reflect an adequate level of systematic thinking by the Minister on the problems which Australia confronts.

There has been in government ranks some evidence that the Government wishes to leap into the type of relationship that Australia had with its major ally in the 1960s. To some extent the Minister's statement reflected that view. Probably at no time since the 1960s has it been more important that this nation's leaders take full advantage of the critical possibilities that years of friendship with the United States permit a country like Australia. It would be wrong to claim substantial influence but ours would probably be more than other powers of an equivalent size, and we are located on the outskirts of regions where the United States is more in need of good advice than anywhere else on the globe.

In the past year the Government has viewed, with a degree of relish, the elevation of military strategic issues to the forefront of international relations and the possibilities for deepening global ideological conflict. In the process it has failed to recognise the extent to which these cut across other international interests which it and we on this side of the House have upheld. The Government endangers a concensus on a sound defence strategy for Australia. It ignores the very real interest that aspects of our relationships with the United States now give us in the sanity and restraint of both super-powers. American facilities in this country give us a very real interest in encouraging caution and stability in the Kremlin as well as in Washington.

The United States is on the verge of committing some serious mistakes in our vicinity-mistakes which this Government recognises but which, if it persists in its current course, it will be powerless to prevent. On the whole, the Government has maintained and nurtured important links with the Third World which were established by the Whitlam Government. It has been committed to this out of principle and a sensible appreciation of the realities of political life in our neighbourhood. These are threatened by some contemporary developments in United States policy. The Reagan Administration in a number of key policy areas foreshadows moves at variance with our stand. They are moves which with increasing ideological confrontation are inevitable. Perhaps nothing exemplifies them better than the embarrassment this Government will experience in respect of its policy toward South Africa. It is quite evident that President Reagan intends to rehabilitate the South African regime. It is all very well to point out, as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) did in answer to a question of mine, that the Reagan Administration opposes apartheid. The point is that instead of that being the fundamental feature of United States-South African policy it is now being shifted to the status of a minor snag-a matter we raise with the South Africans but because of their alleged importance we go no further as we deepen our relationship by grounding it on a mutual security interest. That is a strategy this Government must oppose if it values consistency and its standing in our region. President Reagan expressed his views publicly on the matter while the Foreign Minister was in the United States but there is no record in his statement of his having raised the matter with the President or any of his advisers.

As we have matured over the last decade, imperceptibly Australia and the United States have come to play on different chess boards in the international arena. That appropriate to a super-power is one where every regional issue is seen in a global context, and that which is appropriate to a regional power-ourselves-is where we ought to see every regional issue in terms related to the local situation on the ground, that is, issues of local significance. Our standing in the Commonwealth is very high as is our standing with a variety of nations in the Indian Ocean-Western Pacific regions. That standing has become more important to us than ever it was in the 1960s. There is a price, however, for its maintenance and that is our independence, our willingness to identify with ideological positions and economic priorities which will cut across military-political imperatives in our strategic relations with the United States. The United States at the same time has established a complicated adversary relationship with the Soviet Union which requires a capacity to respond flexibly to Soviet initiatives, to raise and lower tensions over relatively short periods. It is something which the United States can do because its range of interests and agreements with the Soviet Union is so broad. It is not something that an ally of the United States necessarily can do with the same degree of ease and that is becoming increasingly evident in the policies of the European allies of the United States. They are developing close economic relationships with the Eastern bloc. Those economic relationship require stability in the essential relationships between the individual country and the individual Eastern bloc country. They cannot lower and raise the nature of those relationships at will. Therefore they cannot, as the United States can do, respond to every particular Soviet initiative with one of their own. If at some time a catastrophe occurs like a Soviet invasion of Poland then the cut off in relations that will occur between them and the Soviet bloc will not be able, as the American relationship would be in a few years hence, to be subject to the same degree of backing and filling and perhaps a return to a non-cold war stance that the United States could perhaps hope for itself. A major catastrophe involving the Soviet Union would have that effect on the policies of those countries.

Through the B52 agreement negotiated by the Minister while he was away, we are potentially committed to American policy in the Middle East and the Persian Gulf in particular, and yet there is no mention in the Minister's statement of this extremely important area. The B52 aircraft are intimately linked with various scenarios for intervention in the Middle East by the rapid deployment force. General Ellis, of the Strategic Air Command, told Congress last year: No other weapons system can match the B-52 in delivering concentrated conventional firepower on the battlefield. In the opening hours of hostilities, B-52s with 30 tons of explosives can provide timely and effective assistance in disrupting enemy actions. The projected conventional battle scenario is one characterised by minimum warning time followed by a massive attack from highly mobile forces aimed at a rapid breakthrough of defensive lines. In this situation, employment timing is critical. Ground forces need all available firepower in the first 48 hours, preferably applied directly to attacking and supporting forces.

That is not very much time given the terms of the Goverment's agreement on consultation about other than surveillance usage of the B-52s through Darwin. It is now a matter of urgency that we in this country determine whether or not we believe that current directions in United States Middle Eastern policy are appropriate. This includes not only the question of United States policy on Arab-Israeli issues but also the current United States stress on military response to political developments in the region, a stress which is increasingly being rejected by United States allies. It is a matter which is of increasing concern to them because they know and understand what we ought to understand-that the rapid deployment force simply cannot seize the oil installations because there are too many of them over too great a distance for that to be possible. They cannot interdict a Soviet invasion, and a Soviet invasion is most unlikely because the United States and its European allies know, as we ought to know, that if the Soviet Union sought to intervene in the oil fields it would be an action that would strike at the very heart of Western economic survival, and the response to it would have to entail the severe possibility of global nuclear war. That is what deters the Soviet Union in the Middle East, not a rapid deployment force that cannot arrive there in other than a division of strength even at the height of its development, at the apex of what is planned for it, in anything under a month. There is no evidence in the Minister's statement that he has given any serious consideration to this matter.

This country has a direct interest in the stability of the nuclear balance between the Soviet Union and the United States. We have American facilities which monitor compliance with arms control agreements, provide early warning of attack, transmit fire orders to ballistic missile submarines now capable of playing a counterforce role, and assist targeting of Soviet cities and military facilities. The Minister argues, without giving us evidence, that contemporary American military strategy will ensure a stable balance. He owes us more than that. Prima facie contemporary strategy is likely to produce the opposite effect. In SALT II, to be abandoned by President Reagan, the United States has been provided with considerable opportunities to enhance its position with regard to the Soviet Union. No projected qualitative or quantitative change planned in the deployment of American forces is precluded by SALT II-not cruise missiles, not MX missiles, not Trident missiles. On the other hand, a cap is effectively maintained on the deployment of Soviet missiles which are capable of carrying up to 30 warheads as opposed to the current half a dozen warheads.

We have the right to express a view on these issues in the terms of agreements entered into by the Labor Government, and we have a right because of the nature of the facilities that we host. Not to have views on vital issues of nuclear arms control in these circumstances, as the Government has not, is an abdication of responsibility. There are areas of American policy which constitute a reasonable response to aspects of Soviet forward policy. However, there are a substantial number which do not and which will create dissension with American allies and will raise the risk of wrong signals to allies, adversaries and neutrals alike. The Foreign Mininster indicates that he values consistency in the policy of the new American Administration. There is value in consistency but not if one is consistently wrong and when in a complex world achievement of it is unlikely. There is no indication in the Minister's statement that he remotely appreciates these problems.
