SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) and particularly his comments regarding the Reagan Administration. During his statement he said that he was struck by the extent to which the philosophical perspectives and the analysis of the international situation of the Reagan Administration and of the Australian Government coincided. He referred to a shared concern about the Soviet military build-up, the need to maintain a military balance as a condition for stability and effective negotiations, the need to improve consultation and co-ordination within the Western alliance and the need for purposeful American leadership. I welcome this aspect of the statement by the Minister, particularly in view of the reaction by some civic, religious and other community leaders to the statement made recently by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) with respect to the assistance given to the United States of America in its surveillance of the Indian Ocean.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view the arrangements made with the United States to allow B52 bombers access to our Air Force facilities at Darwin are extremely sen- sible. I think Australian sovereignty has not been violated; it has been enhanced by our co-operating with our principal ally in a matter of vital strategic interest to ourselves. We have thereby contributed to our own defence efforts and strengthened the ANZUS Pact on which we so heavily depend. I am at a loss to understand how critics of this policy claim that we have no common interest with the United States in the Indian Ocean. They obviously ignore the fact that the Indian Ocean is increasingly being seen by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics as one of its spheres of influence. I think recent history provides ample evidence of this.

Since Great Britain began its withdrawal from east of Suez in 1967-Britain was then in charge of the key control points in both the eastern and western zones of the Indian Ocean-the Soviet Union has moved in to fill that vacuum. The Soviet Union has treaty agreements with and access to Iraq, South Yemen, Ethiopia, India and, of course, Afghanistan. Each of these countries belongs to the so-called non-aligned movement. Either I do not understand the meaning of the word 'non-aligned' or it is one of the worst misnomers of all time, but the Soviets are on the island of Socotra. In 1976 Mozambique granted the Soviet Union facilities to build air and naval installations at its Indian Ocean bases. Of course there is the improved access of the Soviet navy to the Seychelles.

Since the late 1960s Soviet naval aircraft have undertaken reconnaissance flights over the Indian Ocean. These flights have continued on a periodic basis since that time. A continuous, though fluctuating, naval presence in the Indian Ocean has been maintained, and in the past year Moscow has increased the size of its Indian Ocean fleet to an average presence of about 30 naval units, including guided missile cruisers, frigates and destroyers, nuclear and conventional submarines, supply ships and auxiliary vessels. These naval operations continue to be centred in the areas of access to the Middle East oil fields. Given the dependence of the Western world on Persian Gulf oil, including the substantial dependency of the United States on this source, it is hardly surprising that the Persian Gulf now constitutes the major United States interest in the Indian Ocean. Given recent events in this region, coupled with the increasing Soviet presence there, I am surprised at the way in which the United States is vilified for increasing its military presence in that region. To suggest that Australia and the United States do not have common interests in this matter is absurd.

Any number of commentators give any number of reasons for the Soviet action in this area. Some of these reasons include the securing of a sea link between the Baltic and Vladivostok, the projection of Soviet political and economic power, the denial to the West of access to resources, the opportunity to pressure the oil producing countries as Soviet dependency for outside oil increases, and a long term objective of moving against South Africa and its mineral wealth. These and other reasons have been put forward.

But whatever the real objective may be, I think that three things are obvious: Firstly, Soviet interests and our interests do no coincide; secondly, the Soviet Union is moving to a strategic position which will enable it to achieve its objectives; and thirdly, on the basis of history we can hardly assume Soviet intentions as being based on a desire to spread cheer and goodwill throughout the region. Given this kind of scenario, coupled with the fact that the United States does not control any of the critical geographical locations that affect access to the Indian Ocean, and the critical shortage of United States bases in the Indian Ocean, I strongly support the Government's initiative to assist the United States in its efforts to increase its surveillance of and presence in the Indian Ocean. At present the United States is stretching itself to the limit. The American Commander-in-Chief in the Pacific, Admiral Long, recently told the United States House of Representatives Armed Services Committee:
We cannot go it alone. To the European and Pacific theatres of operations has been added a third, the Indian Ocean and the Persian Gulf.

The United States is at present seeking to increase its presence in Egypt, Oman, Somalia, Kenya and Diego Garcia-but that is all in the future. Obviously the Indian Ocean nations are not doing enough and we, in Australia, must provide the United States with the kind of assistance that we are now offering if our common interests are to be properly served.

I turn briefly to the Israeli-Arab conflict. I was disappointed that the Minister's statement made no direct mention of this matter. I assume that this question is covered by the Minister's referring to the need for purposeful American leadership of the kind which led to the Camp David Accords. I hope that the United States resolve in this issue does not diminish because I have a feeling that the Western world is gradually moving from its long held position of strong support for the State of Israel and that there may be attempts to compromise the security of Israel for other issues. During the early and mid-1970s a shift in the debate on the Arab-Israeli peacemaking effort was taking place. The issue of boundaries was giving way to the issue of the future of the Palestinian Arabs, which we all agree must be satisfactorily resolved. At the same time the United Nations has been questioning the legitimacy of the state of Israel while the Palestine Liberation Organisation was being treated increasingly as a legal entity within the United Nations notwithstanding the fact that the PLO continues to deny the right of Israel to exist in direct contravention of unanimously carried resolutions of the United Nations Security Council. This trend was continued last year by the so-called European initiative whereby the Common Market governments sought to bypass the Camp David Accords, formally to recognise the PLO and to call for the PLO's involvement in negotiations for a Middle East peace settlement.

My further concern in this matter is that the United States Administration, although it made strong pro-Israeli statements during the 1980 election, has not as yet enunciated a policy for dealing with Arab-Israeli tensions. I ask the question: Is the United States, in pursuing broader East-West issues, going to subordinate the Arab-Israeli conflict to that of Persian Gulf security? If so, will the security of Israel be in any way compromised? In my opinion Israel has every reason to be concerned with the long term trends which have been operating on this issue. I believe that the Government should do all in its power to ensure that our support for Israel, as embraced in United Nations Security Council resolutions 242 and 338, is in no way diminished.

I was interested in the Minister's comments regarding the linkage of various elements of any foreign policy, those elements being economic matters, human rights and strategic and political questions. These comments cannot be dissociated from my earlier remarks. I think it is quite proper for the Minister to state that although the Australian Government believes that human rights issues are of the greatest importance it is wrong to assume that economic reform issues and human rights can be divorced from questions of security and strategy. There has been a great deal of public comment on the change in emphasis given to human rights in the formulation of foreign policy under the Reagan Administration compared with the Carter Administration. I think it was Dr Kissinger who said on this subject that power is the basis of foreign policy and only a country with power can have a foreign policy based on morality because only such a country has any choices. This is important in determining perceptions of other nations to the United States. In the Middle East context I think it means that a weakened United States could not behave as responsibly as once it would have done. It was President Assad who said to Kissinger: 'You sold out Vietnam and Cambodia. Why should we not suppose that you will also sell out Israel?' Hence the importance of the United States again reasserting itself, both from a strategic and a moral point of view.

Using human rights as the dominant organising principle of foreign affairs has meant different things to different people. It has created enormous problems for the United States. Those who supported this emphasis constantly sought to discredit successive United States administrations for supporting politically unattractive regimes. They maintained that if such regimes were supported the United States automatically supported their policies. To these advocates the answer was for America to come home while the Soviet Union continued its imperialistic policies. Still other advocates of this principle felt that it provided an opportunity to change things for the better in those nations in which the United States still had some influence. Senator Moynihan, a former United States Ambassador to the United Nations, maintained that the consistent theme of those who placed human rights to the fore in foreign policy decision making was to be more concerned with the wrongdoing of the United States than with other nations that might be adversaries of the United States.

A reliance on human rights alone has led to great difficulties in the United States in recent times. Firstly, it has meant that those seeking accommodation with increasing Soviet power could not, quite correctly, believe that the Russians could be deterred by the threat to them of American words and arguments. Secondly, those in the United States who were prepared to stand up and respond to Soviet power were hindered by the difficulties that United States human rights policies were causing for non-communist, but equally non-democratic, nations which were United States allies. Thirdly, a quite reasonable view has been put forward by the Reagan administration that an overemphasis on human rights undermines authoritarian regimes which have a capacity for change and increases the chance that they will be succeeded by totalitarian governments, specifically communist ones, which obliterate human rights altogether. For these reasons I am pleased that the Minister raised this important issue in his statement. Obviously, if the United States is to give a lead once again to the Western world it will need to provide a greater balance between all the elements of foreign policy formulation, to which the Minister referred, which was obviously lacking in the previous Carter administration.

I wish to comment briefly on the speech made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) late this afternoon in reply to the ministerial statement. In the course of his 27-minute speech he spent 26 1/2 minutes attacking the United States. He did not at any stage criticise the foreign policy of the Soviet Union. He did not refer to the way in which it has behaved in Afghanistan, Angola, Hungary, Poland, Czechoslovakia, South Yemen, Mozambique, the Vietnamese invasion of Kampuchea or any similar issues. I thought his speech was a very unbalanced contribution, characteristic of the speeches of Labor Party spokesman in foreign affairs debates in this Parliament over the last five years. Labor Party spokesmen criticise the United States and Communist China but they will not go out of their way to criticise the Soviet Union. They seek to find a reason to defend the Soviet Union for any expansionist policy it undertakes. I do not welcome the arms build-up around the world. I think all of us would like to see the resources of the world which are now being devoted to arms utilised to feed the millions of starving people and to increase the living standards of those who live in abject poverty. Unfortunately, that is not the reality. Until the Soviet Union and its allies change their international strategy, we have a responsibility to secure and defend this nation and give all the support we can to the United States and her allies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) this afternoon on foreign affairs and those aspects of this Government's policy was disturbing. Throughout the speech ran an emphasis on preparedness for war and a concomitant downplaying of the possibilities of peace. For instance, there was no mention of efforts to reduce international tension between the great powers. For the benefit of the honourable member for Perth (Mr McLean) I include in that description both the Soviet Union and the United States. Detente has obviously become a seven-letter word. The Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the possession of adequate power is desirable precisely because it reduces the chances of armed conflict.
Regrettably, the lessons of history are otherwise. World War I and World War II showed that preparations for war inexorably lead to war.

The Minister has cast Australia as a middle power. I would hope that the main thrust of a middle power would be to bring some sanity to international relations and to seek to reduce the tension between the great powers. This Government has supported, as have previous governments, both Labor and Liberal, the United Nations Declaration on the Indian Ocean which aims to reduce tension in the Indian Ocean. It seeks to set up a zone of peace. There may be some sniggers from the Government on the concept of a zone of peace, but if we cannot get a zone of peace then we will have a zone of war. That is the issue. Very recently, in fact on 12 January this year, the Government supported a United Nations resolution. In part that resolution stated:

Considering that the continued danger posed by the military presence of the great Powers in the Indian Ocean area, conceived in the context of their confrontation, gives greater urgency to the need to take practical steps towards the early achievement of the objectives of the Declaration of the Indian Ocean as a Zone of Peace . . .

That was not simply a statement by a small government. It was a consensus statement in the United Nations that was supported by this Government. Yet in the speech by the Minister for Foreign Affairs no mention was made of this effort to reduce tension in the Indian Ocean area. I point out that the Prime Minister has personally supported a similar resolution. For instance, the communique from the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting in New Delhi in September 1980 stated:

Heads of government noted with concern that despite the expressed wishes of the littoral and hinterland States, great power military presence in the Indian Ocean has increased and that there has been a deterioration of peace and security in the Indian Ocean area. They further noted with regret that recent events in the region, together with the worsening international situation, have caused a further build-up of great power military presence.

Neither of these sane and sensible statements was included in the Minister's speech. Regrettably, in practice the Government has taken steps not to decrease tension but to increase it. Many of us will recall that just prior to the general election, in a fit of ridiculous posturing, the Government dispatched the main operating units of the Royal Australian Navy into the Indian Ocean. It was described as the largest and longest Indian Ocean deployment by the RAN since World War II-again this emphasis on war. The Government said the ships were to exercise with the navies of a number of friendly powers and would visit a large number of ports. The deployment was a monumental flop. There were no major exercises with other navies and the number of ports visited was reduced. In a last minute decision the units were pulled out of an exercise in the northern Indian Ocean with units from the United Kingdom and the United States. That was a sensible decision, but it made a nonsence of the Government's pre-election posturing. So we can say: 'So much for the Minister's only sensible piece of advice in his speech, that we should not extend ourselves unrealistically.'

The Minister's statement is remarkable in another sense. It displays a yawning gap between the principles espoused and the Government's actual performance. The Minister in his speech pointed to a feature of what he describes as middle power foreign policy; that is, that quality of performance is particularly important in determining influence and status. It is regrettable that this Government's quality of performance in a number of areas of foreign policy, particularly in Kampuchea, is deficit in relation to their aims. The Minister dealt with Kampuchea at length in his speech. I want to draw the House's attention to a statement on Kampuchea issued by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs on 14 October 1980. I think the first thing we should note about the statement is the date-14 October 1980, precisely four days before the Federal election. There was, as you will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, a strong criticism within the then Government, the Liberal Party, about relations with Kampuchea. There was a disenchantment among supporters of the Liberal Party about the Government's policy towards Kampuchea in continuing recognition of the Pol Pot regime. So something had to be done in the pre-election panic. The statement that was issued on that occasion was intended to give the impression that the Government had derecognised the Pol Pot regime, Democratic Kampuchea. In fact the statement said:
The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Andrew Peacock, said today that Australia has taken a decision in effect to derecognise the Government of Democratic Kampuchea (the Pol Pot regime).

As we are all aware, it took the Government another four months to the day-14 February 1981-to state that the derecognition of the Government of Democratic Kampuchea, the Pol Pot regime, would take effect as from that day. That statement of 14 October-four days before the election-was nothing more than a deceptive piece of window-dressing. It was in fact a confidence trick.

But there was another deception built into the Government's statement of 14 October. That statement followed by only a few hours instructions to Australia's United Nations delegation to vote in favour of Democratic Kampuchea in the credentialling committee of the United Nations. That meant that Australia, irrespective of what it did a couple of hours later, voted for the continued recognition of the Pol Pot regime. The Government's inconsistency is patently obvious. On the one hand it sought to give the impression that it had derecognised the Pol Pot regime and on the other it voted to continue that recognition. We should remember that the United Nations is the only forum in which recognition of a country with which we do not have diplomatic relations has any relevance. The United Nation is the only organisation in which recognition or derecognition of Democratic Kampuchea has any relevance.

In 1979 the Government adopted the policy-and this is getting back to the history of the credentialling committee-of the previous Liberal-Country Party administrations in arguing, and arguing quite spuriously, that credentialling of delegations in the United Nations is a technical and legal matter and not a matter of policy. For decades the Liberal and Country parties followed that line by denying the very existence of Communist China. By this ploy it upheld the fiction that Taiwan was the rightful government of China. But in 1979 the Australian Government missed an opportunity because in the debate in the United Nations the Indian delegation put forward a proposal-a very sensible proposal-that the seat of Kampuchea should be left vacant. But, oh no, attached to this great ostrich-like policy of continuing to recognise the Pol Pot regime, the Australian delegation voted against the Indian delegation's proposal. One of the consequences of that decision was that the Indian Government then decided to recognise the Heng Samrin regime in Kampuchea. This meant that the support that India could have given to proposals put forward by members of the Association of South East Asian Nations and other countries for a settlement in Kampuchea was lost.

The whole import of what Australia has done in the United Nations has been to continue to give international respectability-it continues today to give international respectability-to the Pol Pot regime because by that vote the Pol Pot regime has full membership status in the United Nations and in the United Nations' specialised agencies and regional organisations for the whole of 1981. That recognition still continues. It is not just an academic question. Only last week the Australian delegation to the United Nations Economic and Social Committee for Asia and the Pacific held in Bangkok and led by a Minister of this Government sat at the very same table as a representative of the Pol Pot regime. The Australian delegation did not protest the presence of the Pol Pot representative. By its action it has continued to recognise the Pol Pot regime.

In short, this Government has misled this House and, more importantly, the Australian people. If it is the intention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs to place an emphasis on the quality of performance of a middle power the first thing that the Government must do is act consistently and act honestly. That is the intent of any foreign policy that an Australian government should seek to perform. This Government has not acted consistently; it has not acted honestly. In fact, it has not acted in the way that we on this side of the House believe Australia as a middle power should perform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating a statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) concerning the nature of this country's foreign policy and some of the more urgent tasks facing us. In replying to the Minister the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) made one comment that I want to take up at this stage. He said that the new United States Administration had scrapped human rights as an instrument of foreign policy. I think that is one of the many dangerous over-simplifications which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition made during his speech. I want to quote from an interview which Mr Alexander Haig, the United States Secretary of State, gave to Time magazine. He was in fact asked a question on that very point. He was asked about the significance of human rights diplomacy in American policy at present, and he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are concerned that open societies sometimes get victimised by the practical consequences of their openness and by the lack of access to information about totalitarian regimes where, it is our conviction, the major abuses to human rights are occurring today. But this is an ancillary problem related to our more strongly held concern that past human rights policies have in many instances been counterproductive, not only to the objective of strengthening human rights but also from the standpoint of vital American interests.
He went on:

There are a number of questions related to this. First and foremost, we must continue to be deeply concerned about abuses to human rights wherever they occur; but there are such questions as whether amelioration of those abuses is best achieved under the glare of public criticism and animosity and confrontation, or whether it is best achieved in a quieter dialogue between states with a healthier relationship.

What I want to point out is that there are many ways of approaching human rights questions, many ways of trying to deal with them where we are dealing with relationships with sovereign countries, and I think it is unreasonable to assert in a sweeping manner that the United States has effectively scrapped human rights as an instrument of foreign policy. There can be differences about approach, there can be differences about the end result of various courses of action with respect to human rights and how effective various courses of action may be, but in fact it is still a very strong element of United States policy, and indeed should be.

Mr Haig's remarks point to a problem that we face in Australia. There is tendency in Australia, in talking about human rights problems, to emphasise problems that appear in countries such as Indonesia, the Philippines and South Korea. These are countries which are more open than many of the communist or left wing countries in the region. Therefore one has a greater opportunity to find out about instances of breaches of human rights. However, one does not have the same opportunity to obtain information about what is happening in more closed societies, in societies which are often run by socialist or communist governments, or governments that claim to have that complexion. So effectively a great public emphasis on human rights issues can lead to a sense of protection being given to closed societies which do not allow us to find out what is going on in their countries compared with more open societies where there is a greater possibility for use to move in or send people in to find out what is happening and therefore bring the abuses of human rights to light. That is one of the difficulties that those of us in Australia who want to take action on human rights face in dealing with the situation in an even-handed manner.

The honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) said that the lessons of World War I and World War II show that preparations for war inexorably led to war. There is an element of truth in that, but perhaps the word 'inexorably' is overstating it. Many others would say that preparations for war ensure that we do not face war in future because we deter future enemies. The example that is commonly given to support that argument is the example of the development of power in nazi Germany in the 1930s and the lack of response by democratic countries to that challenge which was obviously looming on the horizon. What we want is not an oversimplified statement about preparations for war; what we want is a realistic assessment of what is happening in the world and an appropriate response to what that assessment shows.

With that in mind I want to examine some of the attitudes being adopted by the Reagan Administration towards the Soviet Union, and then to look at the implications of those attitudes for Australian foreign policy. One of the problems in American attitudes towards the Soviet Union, in recent years is that there has tended to be a swing from one unreal view to another. In some circles in the United States there has been an undue naivety about the potential to reach some peaceful accommodation with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. It was an attitude evident in much of the eastern liberal academic establishment of the United States of America. Many people in that category tended to take the view that if only we understood the USSR and got to know each other as people through more cultural exchanges, sporting contacts, regular consultations, et cetera, our fears of the USSR would fade and we would come to realise that we are all human beings of peaceful intent with common interests. Some people who take this view have a tendency to be highly critical of American leadership for supposedly having passed up opportunities to lessen tensions between the two super-powers. In my view these unreal expectations arise from a lack of knowledge, of Russian history, both czarist and Bolshevik, and a lack of understanding of the essential dynamics of policies arising from Marxist-Leninist theories. The Soviet Union sees itself as being on the historically correct side of a fundamental ideological conflict between the forces of socialism and the forces of capitalism. These factors incline the Soviet Union towards an aggressive and expansionist attitude. Add to this some of the tensions within the Soviet Union itself, the failure of its economy to deliver the standard of living which had been promised to the Soviet people, and that increases also the likelihood that any Soviet government will be looking for outside adventures or at least be looking for some outside tensions which it can use to distract attention from problems within the country.

Certainly we must understand the very real fears of the Russian people, the people who suffered at the hands of nazi Germany in the Second World War. A very real basis of fear exists among people in the Soviet Union, perhaps even to the extent of some sort of xenophobic attitude towards countries around the Soviet Union. That is something that we must bear in mind and with which we must sympathise. At the same time we must realise that there are essential forces within Soviet societies, within Marxist and Leninist theory, which tend to give the Soviet Union an expansionist attitude towards the rest of the world. One problem with the unreal attitude towards the Soviet Union, which I described earlier that if only we could get to know each other as people a bit more then tensions would lessen, is that when some incident occurs which breaks down that attitude of trust and general bonhomie, it can lead to a swing in the direction of excessive mistrust and bellicosity. So one can get a return to the bluster, the abuse, and the general tense language of Cold War rhetoric. We all recall, for example, how President Carter made himself look a rather pathetic figure when he complained, after the Soviet Union invasion of Afghanistan, that the Soviet Union had misled him. We then saw something of a tendency in the United States for congressmen, for leading spokesmen on public opinion, to swing towards bellicosity and sabre rattling in the terms of their attitudes to foreign relations and in particular their attitudes towards Russia.

What then do we make of the rather strident statements which are now coming from President Reagan and Secretary of State Haig? A common fear being expressed by many commentators is that the language of Mr Reagan and Mr Haig may raise unnecessarily the temperature of relationships and increase the risk of some genuine misunderstanding arising between the super-powers about their intentions. That misunderstanding could then raise the risk of actual conflict. Doubtless the new Administration feels that the United States needs to show more resolve and purpose in its foreign policies than has been demonstrated in recent years. Perhaps some stiffening of United States resolve is indeed needed at this stage. In that respect, the recent statements by President Reagan may reflect the developments that would have occurred under any President likely to be elected in the current political atmosphere. By now, however, I think, the rhetorical points have been made. I think some degree of excessive emotionalism has been used in some of the language that has come out of Washington, but that United States resolve should now be expressed by way of the iron fist in a velvet glove approach rather than by waving a cutlass around accompanied by blood curdling screams. Neither United States leaders nor Australian leaders should fall into the trap of abusing the Soviet Union and its leaders merely to satisfy some emotional requirement in themselves.

In the Australian context, as we are developing closer and more fruitful relationships with China, it is particularly easy to see our interests in the short term being served by a stridency towards the Soviet Union that brings satisfied smiles to the faces of Chinese trade delegations. I have probably fallen into this trap myself in the presence of affable Chinese officials when we have both found common cause in bemoaning the tendencies of the Soviet Union. I believe we would be wise to ensure that our foreign policy does not tip too strongly in favour of China vis-a-vis the Soviet Union. After all, the United States opening to China under the Nixon Administration, by which Australia's rapprochement with China became more possible, was not an initiative designed to form some United States-China alliance against the Soviet Union. Both President Nixon and Dr Kissinger, the then National Security adviser and after that Secretary of State were at great pains to point out that the detente with China was not intended to lead to a United States-China condominium to surround the Soviet Union. Rather it was seen as a way of bringing China out of her isolation and ensuring China her rightful place in an overall world balance.

I do not believe our desire to pursue harmonious relationships with China should lead us to court unnecessary aggravations in any relationship we have with the Soviet Union. In other words, we do not need to be rude to the Russians in order to charm the Chinese. I do not say this in any belief that we can afford to be soft or complacent in our attitude to the Soviet Union. On the contrary, as I said earlier, we must be fully aware of the fundamental ideological struggle between the Soviet Union and western liberal democracies and the possibility of this developing into armed conflict at various points around the world.

This has implications for Australian foreign policy. Within the context of that super-power relationship between the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics I believe we have a very real role to play. There is no real alternative to Australia being part of the American alliance in both a military and diplomatic sense. Ideologically our society has nothing in common with basic Marxist structures, no matter how much any briefly fashionable romantics in our country like to wear Mao badges or pay homage to whatever other Marxist leader happens to be in vogue at the time. Our commitment to Western Liberal democratic traditions and the basic freedoms of such societies gives us a fundamental common interest with the United States. The Australian people would feel that they have some natural alliance with the American people whether or not that alliance was formalised in a treaty. In fact, it is formalised in a treaty in the form of the ANZUS treaty. That treaty allows us to play a constructive role of influence in our relationships with the United States. We have the opportunity of having some input into United States policy considerations. We share the results of intelligence gathering, a matter of great benefit to Australia. I believe that also imposes on us a responsibility to play a part in enabling the United States to carry out its global responsibilities.

I do not want to suggest that the American alliance is the be-all and end-all of all Australian foreign policy and defence policy. We must develop our own regional network of bilateral and multilateral relationships. Under this Government we have developed practical working relationships with a number of countries in our region.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very disappointed and saddened by the ease with which the new Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) has so quickly and pliantly fallen into line to comply with what we see as the tunnel vision of his leader, the hard-line people in his party and the reactionary leaders in the world today such as the Reagans and the Thatchers. It is very sad that those people tend to see things in black and white; they do not see anything in between. Other people are either with them or against them. They do not try to understand the point of view of the other side. The Minister for Foreign Affairs visited countries which he refers to as like-minded countries. They include most of the Association for South East Asian Nation countries-Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia. He also visited places such as Tokyo, Peking and Washington. He says that those countries are like-minded. He should realise that all those countries still support the Pol Pot regime which we have only belatedly derecognised. If those countries are like-minded he is being very honest in saying that at least they still support the Pol Pot regime and that they see people who support the Pol Pot regime as like-minded people.

It is a great shame that the Minister did not try to be better informed by talking to officials in some countries which were not like-minded which may have been able to enlighten him and give him a more objective view of the situations on the ground. The Minister did not go to any of those countries. If he had he would have had a different view. By talking only to like-minded people how does one get out of having a tunnel vision of the situation in those countries? Of course, the tunnel vision leads the Minister to the wrong conclusion-as it has led the Government to the wrong conclusion-that communism and big power politics are the enemy particularly in South East Asia.

The Government should be looking toward going back to the root-cause of the problem in South East Asia. The root-causes of the problem are the denial of basic human rights to the population at large in many of those countries; gross poverty and starvation for millions of people; gross underdevelopment; and gross corruption in many of the regimes. These are the problems to which we should address ourselves, not some vague abstraction called communism. That tunnel vision leads people to the further view that instability in those countries is caused by big power involvement. There is no question about the fact that big powers become involved. Big powers are involved in Kampuchea. Their involvement is made possible by the instability in those countries caused by the poverty, the underdevelopment and, in some cases-as in Kampuchea and Vietnam-by the involvement of Western countries such as the United States of America. Western countries went into that region and created the conditions which allowed instability to develop. They destroyed the social infrastructure of those countries, and moved out and left a vacuum. Extreme people such as Pol Pot were able to move into that vacuum with devastating effects on the community. We did the same sort of thing in Vietnam. We said: 'The problem is that the south is being invaded from the north', without looking at the internal position in South Vietnam. The instability was internal and not caused only by external forces.

We seem to be making the same sorts of judgments in South East Asia, Kampuchea and, of course, El Salvador. I am sorry that the Minister did not look at these countries, make himself better informed and form a more balanced view of what is going on.

My wife and I recently visited Vietnam, Kampuchea and Phnom Penh. We found that visit very interesting and very enlightening. We came back with a much better balanced view of what is happening in these countries. If the Minister had gone there he would have a different view from the one he has expressed. He would not have any truck at all with countries which are supporting the Pol Pot regime, or he would try to encourage them to derecognise Pol Pot. If the Minister or anybody else has any doubts about the demonic and horrendous nature of the Pol Pot regime they should look at the photographs which my wife took on the outskirts of Phnom Penh where thousands of human skeletons are being dug out of the ground. Mainly these are skeletons of women and children. It is stark and horrendous evidence of how bad the Pol Pot regime was.

If one were to go there and see that and talk to the people one would not be talking about the Vietnamese invading Kampuchea. There is no question that the people in Phnom Penh today see the Vietnamese as their saviours. They are regarded as fraternal people who came in to save them from the horrors of Pol Pot. These people are damned glad to be alive. They recognise that. On our visit to Phnom Penh we would not have know the Vietnamese presence was there. We did not see one Vietnamese soldier in Phnom Penh. We knew they were there because the Kampuchean people told us they were being assisted by the Vietnamese. We know they have 200,000 troops in the north keeping the Pol Pot forces in check. I can assure honourable members that they are exercising a very benign influence over the Kampucheans.

The Kampuchean economy is developing in a complete laissez faire, free market atmosphere. The Heng Samrin regime is allowing the normal market forces to operate so that the country can develop an economy. The proof is shown in the fact that there are now 300,000 people back in Phnom Penh. They are coming back in large numbers. Many of them have come out of the refugee camps which twelve months ago were seen as an insoluble problem. They are coming back because they have confidence in the Heng Samrin regime and in the way in which it is running the country. The children are back at school. There are not many teachers because Pol Pot cut the throats of most of them. Agriculture is recovering rapidly. The regime has the support of the people in Phnom Penh. I did not get out into the country so I cannot speak for the people there. I have read of other people who have toured extensively through the country and the story is the same: They are very grateful for the fact that the Vietnamese came in and saved them from the Pol Pot regime. To talk about the Vietnamese invading the Kampucheans, dominating them and standing over them is a complete misreading of the situation.

I can understand the Minister's holding that view because he did not talk to anybody who has a different view and he did not go and look for himself. If he had done so he would have seen that the Vietnamese were not aggressors. If the Kampucheans want the Vietnamese to get out they know what to do. All they have to do is to encourage some of their like-minded friends to derecognise Pol Pot and stop giving him support, and the Vietnamese will withdraw the next day. It is very costly for the Vietnamese to be in Kampuchea. They do not want to be there but they will not turn their backs on their brothers in Kampuchea and let them be slaughtered by Pol Pot. It is just not on.

It is quite absurd for the Minister to talk about supporting the third force. The third force is comprised of people who are not even in Kampuchea. It has very little grassroots support. It is absolute nonsense to talk of supporting the third force led by Prince Sihanouk or anybody else. The reality of the situation is that the Vietnamese are there. They will stay there. They have been there for a long time. They have supported the Kampucheans consistently. They supported them in getting rid of the French. They supported them against the Lon Nol regime and they have now supported them in getting rid of Pol Pot. There is nothing new about Vietnam supporting Kampuchea. More and more countries are now recognising that the Indo-China region is a legitimate area of influence of Vietnam. Vietnam has a population of 40 million or 50 million people. Kampuchea and Laos are both very small countries. They are vital to the peace and prosperity of Vietnam.

As I said, my wife and I went to Vietnam. It is a very rundown country. It is badly in need of aid and support. I found it very distressing and I felt quite ashamed of our Government in that the little bit of aid that we were giving them was cut off. The condensed milk factory which we sent them is sitting in crates. There is nobody there to assemble it. We sent them 600 head of beef cattle. We were supposed to follow up with a pasture improvement program. In a very petty act we just cut off that program. Whilst it was only symbolic support, its being stopped has created very bad feeling between our Government and the Government of Vietnam, although the Vietnamese know there are many people in Australia who would not have agreed with what happened. It is a great shame that the Minister did not go and look at that area, but I know that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) would not want him to go to see the situation for himself. The Government has a tunnel vision about what is going on in the country and does not want that disturbed.

Normally we take our lead from the Association of South East Asian Nations in developing a policy towards Kampuchea. On this occasion, although publicly the ASEAN nations are saying they are opposed to the Vietnamese, privately at least two of them, the Indonesians and the Malaysians, have some sympathy for the Vietnamese position. I am sure that when the election, which is being held in April, takes place, the present regime will be endorsed. It is acceptable to the people there. I think at that time many countries will recognise the reality of the situation and will recognise that regime. At some stage we have to think about doing that and getting on with the job of sending real aid-development aid, humanitarian aid-to these countries, particularly Kampuchea and Vietnam.

I wish to say a few words briefly on El Salvador. This is another example of a misguided policy of the Americans insisting on sending guns when the President of El Salvador stated that the strongest army in the world would not overcome the problems of poverty and starvation in that country. It is nonsense for us to be screaming out about these people acquiring arms. My son visited that country last year. He wrote to me and stated how horrifying it was to see, 12 months ago, the national guard in El Salvador shooting demonstrators in the back. In the last 12 months thousands of innocent peasant people in El Salvador have been shot down with weapons which were supplied by the Americans to the national guard in El Salvador. What are these people to do? Are they to sit down and be shot? Of course they will secure weapons. Whether they get them from the Americans or a communist country is irrelevant. These people are driven to desperation. They have to defend themselves. It does not matter where they get the weapons from.

If the Americans listened to the advice of the President of the Government of El Salvador, they would be aware that he said: 'We do not want guns. We want economic aid. We want to be able to develop our country. We want to be able to feed ourselves'. But the Americans say: 'No, you do not want aid. You want more guns to shoot all these revolutionary people'. That is the situation as it is developing in El Salvador today. I think anyone who really believes that in the long term we can sustain indefinitely this gross social injustice involving the majority of the people in the world, mainly those in the underdeveloped countries of the Third World who are living in abject poverty, fighting starvation and undevelopment without basic health and education facilities, shows no understanding of the recognition of the continued long term progress towards social justice to which every nation is entitled.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to establish a Commonwealth Human Rights Commission. The Commission will promote the observance of human rights throughout Australia within the limits of Commonwealth power. In co-operation with the States on human rights matters the Commission will assist the Government in discharging its international obligations in the cause of human rights. Our intention to introduce this legislation was foreshadowed in the Government's policy speech prior to the last election. The most recent attempt by this Government to have Parliament approve a human rights commission foundered because of lack of agreement between this House and the Senate on what became known as the Simon amendment, and was related to the rights of the child before as well as after birth. The Government has arrived at a formula, included in this Bill, which it believes will be acceptable both to those who voted for and those who voted against the amendments.

Since the Human Rights Commission Bill 1979 was debated in this House last year, several events have transpired which only add to the need for effective human rights machinery in Australia. In August 1980, Australia ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. To date 65 countries have become parties to this Covenant, many of which have established their own special forms of machinery to promote and protect human rights. The measure now before the House, and the Commission that would be established under it, will help Australia to discharge the obligations it has assumed under the covenant.

Last August, as well, the Government established the Human Rights Bureau as an interim measure pending creation of a human rights commission. Recently, the Bureau has begun to receive representations from the public in the form of complaints, requests for assistance, and requests for information in the general field of human rights. The Bureau has also made significant progress in establishing links with non-government organisations in the human rights field. It is apparent, however, that there is a need for more effective machinery to promote human rights in Australia than is available through the Bureau, and it is the object of the Bill to provide this machinery. The Commission will not be a large undertaking. Its emphasis will be on quality. Its annual cost is currently estimated at about $850,000, to which will be added the cost of the Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations-estimated at $350,000 in 1980-81.

The main provisions of the Bill are the same as in the Bill considered by the House last year. As such, they have already been the subject of considerable discussion and debate. I intend in this speech, therefore, to refer to and explain only those changes from the 1979 Bill that are found in the present measure. The only change of significance is that the charter of the Commission has been extended to three additional international instruments. As with the previous Bill, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights will be the primary point of reference for the Commission. However, in response to the concern expressed in this House, and also in the Senate, during the debate on the Simon amendment about the rights of both children and handicapped persons, the Commission will also be required to have regard, in areas of Commonwealth responsibility, for the rights of these groups as recognised in three international declarations, each of which has been supported by Australia. The three declarations are-the Declaration of the Rights of the child, 1959; the Declaration on the Rights of the Mentally Retarded, 1971; and the Declaration on the Rights of the Disabled, 1975.

The Declaration of the Rights of the Child recognises that the Child, by reason of his physical and mental immaturity, needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth. The declaration also calls upon men and women everywhere, on voluntary organisations and on governments to strive for the observance of the rights of the child which it proclaims. The rights include the right to special protection to enable the child to develop fully; the right to enjoy the benefits of social security, including adequate pre-natal and post-natal care; and the rights to education and to protection from cruelty and exploitation. Similarly, the two declarations concerned with the rights of physically and intellectually handicapped persons call for national and international action to protect the rights they declare. The rights of the intellectually handicapped include the right to be accorded as far as possible the same rights as other persons; the right to economic security and a decent standard of living; and the right to protection from exploitation, abuse and degrading treatment. The rights of the physically handicapped include the right to the same civil and political rights as other persons; the right to respect for their human dignity; the right to measures to enable them to become as self-reliant as possible; and the rights to medical and other treatment and to economic and social security and a decent level of living.

The three declarations I have just been describing do not represent commitments in international law, as does the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. But they express important aspirations, and we are proposing that the Commission should monitor, and report on, the way in which Commonwealth departments and agencies, and activities generally in the Australian Capital Territory, are conforming with them. The three declarations are defined in clause 3 of the Bill, and are included in the definition of 'human rights' in the same clause. There are consequential amendments, chiefly in clause 31, which envisage the declaration of further international instruments as part of the Commission's charter.

During debate on the 1979 Bill and in the ensuing months, comments have been made about certain aspects of the 1979 Bill that are repeated in the present Bill. Because they are apparently the source of some concern, I should like to discuss three of those criticisms. The first is that the scope of the proposed Commission would extend only to laws of the Commonwealth and the Territories-except the Northern Territory-and actions or procedures under such laws. The Commission's mandate will not extend to State or Northern Territory laws or actions or procedures of State and Northern Territory authorities. However, clause 11 of the Bill provides for a range of co-operative arrangements to be entered into with the States and it is the Government's intention and expectation that this mechanism will be fully used.

The ministerial meeting on human rights will continue to exercise a role at top policy level in considering issues which require consultation between the various levels of government and in promoting generally the cause of human rights in Australia. Accordingly, this Bill manifests the Government's continuing commitment to co-operative federalism, which is already developing well in the human rights field. The second criticism levelled at the 1979 Bill is that the proposed Commission would incorporate the Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations. Non-government organisations in the human rights field have particularly voiced this concern. It is motivated by a fear that the work done by the Commissioner for Community Relations will somehow be interrupted or curtailed. The Government's expectation is in fact quite the opposite. Let me emphasise, as I did when the previous Bill was before the House, that the Commissioner for Community Relations will continue to carry out the complaint-handling and conciliation functions associated with administration of the Racial Discrimination Act. Further, the added resources of the Commission will be available to assist as required in the important task of combating racial discrimination, and there will be a recourse, as there was not previously, to the Meeting of Ministers on Human Rights on racial discrimination matters.

The Government is confident, therefore, that establishing the Commission will not make less effective the role of the Commissioner for Community Relations in dealing with complaints of racial discrimination. Thirdly, there have been criticisms that the Human Rights Commission is being given inadequate powers-that it has no machinery for enforcement of its findings. That criticism represents a misunderstanding of the essential purpose of the Commission. The purpose of the Commission is to promote discussion and understanding of human rights in the community generally and to recommend to the Government and to Parliament changes in law or practice required to bring that law and practice into line with human rights as defined by the International Covenant or other human rights instruments. For its job, the Commission has been given adequate powers to obtain papers, to call witnesses, to conduct hearings and to make reports. A survey of institutions with similar functions in Australia and overseas shows that the Commission is as well, or better, endowed with powers than other bodies having similar functions.

What the critics of the Commission suggest is that it should have some kind of court-like powers of enforcement. In the view of the Government, this may be a possible step for the future, but it is not the next step, which is establishment of the Commission. It is only when the Parliament has laid down laws relating to human rights in a particular area-for example relating to racial discrimination-that the normal law enforcement machinery should be considered. Even there, the clear cut and authoritative decisions of the courts may not be the correct way to proceed, at any rate in the early stages of the operation of the law. The promotion of human rights in this country will be achieved more through education, through finding new balances of interests and through conciliation than through firm measures of enforcement. In closing, I should like to refer to the final paragraph of my second reading speech for the 1979 Bill. The thoughts and hopes expressed are as current and important today as they were then. I said:

Human rights are about the protection of individuals. I believe, and the Government believes, that in an era of social change in which governments exercise wide powers and corporations and large institutions greatly influence the lives of individuals, it is important to have an agency that is active in the protection and promotion of the rights of individuals. We see in the world around us too many occasions where the rights of individuals are cruelly violated. The purpose of the Human Rights Commission, and of the machinery associated with it, is to help Australia maintain its excellent record in the protection of human rights, and progressively to develop a better and more comprehensive recognition and observance of the rights of every individual in our community, regardless of financial standing and whatever his or her race, age, sex, religion or status.
I commend the Bill to the House.
