TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate will be allowed on both this Bill and the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate on the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill was adjourned I was pointing out how important it is in any democratic society that citizens have the right and the means to seek redress for injustices perpetrated by organs of the state, including the police. In Australia one such important organ is the Australian Federal Police and the Bill provides the public with the means of achieving a satisfactory investigation of almost all types of grievances linked with the Australian Federal Police. Most importantly, the Bill seeks to establish a mechanism that will not hamstring members of the Australian Federal Police in carrying out their vital role in the community. By strengthening the role of the Ombudsman, the Bill seeks to strike a sensible balance between providing the public with a guarantee that their grievances will be energetically and conscientiously investigated and, at the same time, screening the authorities from malicious and destructive complaints.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Bill still has some minor gaps which could be plugged. I refer to the provision by which the Ombudsman has the power to hire police officers to investigate particular complaints. This is set out fairly clearly. It would be to the benefit of the legislation and would assist the Ombudsman if that power were extended to the hiring of former police officers. Although some people may be sceptical of the objectivity of a former officer, since there is provision for the hiring of existing police officers in certain circumstances, there could be very good grounds for hiring a former police officer if it were clear that a deep knowledge of police procedure would be a great advantage in ensuring a thorough investigation. I am sure that the Ombudsman's office would exercise that right with great discretion. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner) may care to comment on that proposal.

My other concern with the Bill is the potential problem presented by the sub judice law. The Minister may care to comment on that matter also and indicate whether the Ombudsman could be inhibited in any way by such law. It could happen frequently that, the police having taken action against a citizen, as a result of which charges have been laid, the citizen may wish to lay a counter-charge against the police. I can imagine a situation in which the Ombudsman may be inhibited in his investigation by the sub judice law. I believe he would use his discretion in handling such a situation. However, it could present a problem and I would like the Minister to make clear whether the Ombudsman would be inhibited by the sub judice law.

When many complaints are being made against the police it often becomes quite apparent that problems of morale exist within the police force itself. That has been my experience in the Australian Capital Territory. The recent amalgamation of the old Commonwealth Police and the Australian Capital Territory Police was characterised by many teething problems. Over time many of these have been eliminated, but others remain. In that respect, I know that members of the Protective Services Division feel that they have been disadvantaged in the amalgamation, in regard to wages and salaries in particular. I believe they have a legitimate complaint. A recent determination, of August 1980, although it covered people performing general police duties did not extend benefits to members of the Protective Services Division, who lag considerably behind other officers in that respect. It is possible for police officers performing exactly the same work to be receiving significantly different rates of pay-the difference sometimes being as much as $2,000 a year. The present Minister has been sympathetic to complaints made by the Protective Services Division and I believe he will continue to examine these problems and overcome them as they arise. Many of the initial problems have been overcome, but the wages issue is still a matter of concern for quite a few officers.

Another problem is that there is still difficulty in obtaining suitable uniforms for some policemen and policewomen. I understand that there are no winter uniforms available for the women members of the Protective Services Division, and with winter coming up pretty quickly, the Government should apply itself to the problem and ensure that the morale of the people performing this important work is maintained. If there is good morale in the force fewer complaints are made against it by the public. The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill 1981 is an important step forward for Australia. I hope that its spirit will be copied by all other States. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to compliment the Australian Law Reform Commission, which, as all honourable members know, is headed by Mr Justice Michael Kirby, on the success it has had over the years. It could be said that the Commission has not won approval for everything it has recommended. I suggest it has won more approval than the Opposition and the back bench of the Government side of this Parliament have managed to win in the last five, six or even ten years. Not everything put forward by the Law Reform Commission commands my agreement, but it has had more than its share of success. The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill is one example of its suggestions not only being taken seriously by the Government but also being acted upon and incorporated in the nation's legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am keen to speak on this Bill so that I can express the view that this legislation should be regarded as the ideal by all State police forces within the Commonwealth of Australia. As you are fully aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, I come from the State of Queensland. I think that was your home State before you shifted to New South Wales. Undoubtedly the Queensland Police Force, like the police force of every other State, is subjected to varying degrees of criticism from time to time. Some say that the Queensland Police Force is the worst in Australia for its appreciation of the liberties of the individual, and others say that from time to time police forces from other States take that prize.

I do not intend to enter into the question of which State has the best or the worst police force. However, I make the observation that an individual policeman is in some cases probably without full appreciation or knowledge of the power that he possesses. There lies in his hands a greater ability to destroy the lifestyle of an individual than perhaps lies in the hands of the vast majority of the members of this House and the Senate. An arrest involving the action of bricking, which all honourable members will realise is the falsification of evidence, or even an arrest based on the personal reaction of a policeman to the behaviour of a person being apprehended can have an effect on a person's life which goes with him or her to the grave. Even the wrongful stopping of a person along the road for a suspected motor offence can have an effect on that person's life at a later stage.

I said earlier that I see this legislation as ideal, and it is my fervent wish that every State government, irrespective of its political persuasion, study the contents of this legislation, which should be an example to the police forces of the nation. I have long held the view that in a number of occupations one simply cannot win. Those occupations cannot be free of controversy, and do not always have the respect of the public. Politics is one of those arenas. The public will always be divided. The lot of a policeman is not that much different. With politicians, a love-hate relationship exists. The same applies to the police force. A person in trouble cannot ring a policeman quickly enough. A person free of trouble is likely to be either highly critical of police force actions or praiseworthy. The community divides on that subject. Not everybody loves the copper. I think in the Sydney Daily Telegraph today a cartoon showed policemen combing Kings Cross. Someone popping up through a manhole-that represented the underworld-said something to the effect: 'We are trying to keep undesirables out of this district. Why don't you beat off?'

In a nutshell, I am saying that a policeman will not always be given credit and be on top. However, one of the inescapable facts is that there are members of the police force who will let the team down. There are policemen who will put their lives at total risk. Many have paid the supreme sacrifice in their efforts to protect John Citizen or save him from one of the accidents about which we read from time to time. Many have laid down their lives. I think that overall the police forces of this country have given far more to the community than they have ever asked for in return. However, as with the proverbial barrel of apples, there is always a rotten one. This legislation gives the aggrieved John Citizen the opportunity to report an injustice that he believes has been perpetrated.

This legislation will leave open the way for involvement by the Ombudsman. It is opportune to reflect that the role of the Ombudsman since the creation of his position not so many years ago has been greatly enlarged. When a situation gets hot it seems to suit governments of all political persuasions to write a reference in legislation to the Ombudsman so he can settle the matter. The combination of the involvement of the Ombudsman and the Internal Investigation Division of the Australian Federal Police will go a long way towards ensuring that where a rotten apple causes an overall poor reflection on a police force that rotten apple will have to answer to somebody at some time. One of the facts of life that I have come to appreciate as I make my way through my three score years and ten is that 100 men can do something, but if one man does the wrong thing the public-including all members of this House-will spend more time talking about that one man who has done the wrong thing than about the 99 people who have spent their lives doing the right or good thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mark Antony's oration said the same thing, but not so eloquently.
—I remember that the honourable member's name is Barry Jones, but I do not remember the electorate he represents. He is somewhat praiseworthy in his observations.
—Order! All honourable members will address the Chair and not each other.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate the interjection. Perhaps it is every 2,000-odd years that a man with similar wisdom passes through this world. As I was saying, this legislation allows that rotten apple to be torn from the barrel. I believe the respect in which the Australian Federal Police Force is presently held will grow as a result of this legislation. I do not wish to repeat the aspects of the legislation which were outlined by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner) in his second reading speech and by other speakers, but I make a special appeal to all the State Ministers of police, including the Queensland Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police, the Honourable Russell Hinze, to examine this legislation closely to see what it offers and to balance in their minds the criticism which is directed to their police forces with the high respect in which the Australian Federal Police is held. In so doing they should remember that even though the Australian Federal Police Force is held on a very high pinnacle, this Parliament sees this legislation as being necessary. Indeed, I believe the Whitlam Goverment in 1975 attempted to introduce similar legislation and it was the eclipse of that reign which caused the legislation to go into limbo. Two or three years after that this Government recognised that there was still a need for this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst we can all allude to experiences that we have had with various police forces, I believe it is probably appropriate that I do not introduce matters of a personal nature. I conclude by simply reminding the various State governments that this legislation is setting a new standard and providing a new opportunity for the Australian people to report their grievances and to feel assured that their grievances against the police will be fully investigated. That in itself not only protects the Australian public but also ensures the enshrinement of the high standard which so many of the nation's policemen endeavour to attain but which is so often eroded by the actions of one or two irresponsible individuals who should have never been given the power in the first place.

My final observation is one that I made earlier in my comments, namely, that so many policemen fail to realise that in their hands more than in those of me in this Parliament lies the power to destroy or to make so many individual lives in our community. Occasionally some of them truly fumble that ball which causes irreparable damage to be inflicted upon the lives of people who are basically as decent if not better than themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the Opposition side of the House to support this legislation because I see it as an improvement. As the last honourable member who spoke, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron), said it is an improvement even on much of the State legislation. I am not aware of all the legislation in the States but I am aware of the legislation in NSW and I must admit that this is an improvement on that. Let me quickly refresh the memories of honourable members as to what this Bill when dealing with the handling of complaints against members of the Australian Federal Police actually proposes could be done. The second reading speech of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A complaint by a member of the public as to police conduct may be made to a police officer or to the Ombudsman; where made to a police officer, the Ombudsman must be notified.
I think that is an important point. It further states:
Complaints as to practices and procedures of the force will ordinarily be investigated by the Ombudsman.
That refers to general practices and procedures and not specific complaints against an individual member of the Police Force. The speech continues:
Other complaints as to the police, that is to say, complaints as to conduct of individual officers, will be investigated initially by the Internal Investigation Division previously mentioned.
That is, the Internal Investigation Division which is set up in the police force. The speech continues:

If the Ombudsman is dissatisfied with the report of the Investigatin Division on a complaint, he may ask for a further investigation by the Investigation Division or he may carry out an investigation by his own office.
I think that is a very important point and I will refer to it again when I deal with the criticism of what the Ombudsmen in other States are doing. The speech continues:
The Minister may, on his own initiative, establish a special inquiry into any matter relating to the Force.

. . . The Ombudsman may recommend that criminal or disciplinary charges should be brought against a member; if the Commissioner does not agree with the recommendation, the matter shall be referred to the Attorney-General, who shall decide what charges, if any, should be brought.

Criminal charges against a police officer will be brought in the ordinary courts; disciplinary charges originating from a complaint from a member of the public will be dealt with by the Federal Police Disciplinary Tribunal to be established under the legislation;

I will not go into details as to what the exact method of appeals and so on is, but I think basically the important point is that there is a method for investigating the Police Force. One of the great difficulties when one is dealing with complaints against the Police Force is that there is nobody in the community adequately capable of investigating complaints, apart from the Police Force itself. It is a problem that has arisen in Australia and it is a problem which, probably because we have some similarity with the United States of America and the United Kingdom, has repeatedly been portrayed in films and television programs dealing with policemen who have transgressed the law or people who have made allegations against those policemen. I think it is an important improvement that there is provision for the Ombudsman to investigate the problems. Let me quote from the report of the Ombudsman of NSW for the year ended 30 June 1979. It is the latest printed report but not the latest report prepared. The Ombudsman, Mr Smithers, is a fairly conservative gentleman who is about to retire. He is certainly not an extremely radical person who tends to criticise the Police Force unnecessarily. In the report he states:
I have experienced some feelings of frustration in carrying out my functions under the Act as the powers of investigation are very different to those under the Ombudsman Act.
He is talking about investigating the police. He continues:

Under that Act I can obtain information from any public authority, inspect papers, obtain reports, enter premises and interview anyone and I can carry out a formal investigation if I think it warranted. None of these powers apply under the provisions of the Police Regulation (Allegations of Misconduct) Act. My function under that Act is restricted. I receive complaints, making a decision as to whether there should be an investigation or endeavour to conciliate if it might be appropriate. I then refer the complaint to the Commissioner for Investigation, I receive a report from him, I decide whether it is properly investigated, and when the investigation is completed then decide whether the complaint has been sustained or not and report accordingly. Under this Act--
That is the New South Wales Act-
I do not investigate in the full sense, I merely act in a supervisory capacity and finally report to the complaint on the result of the investigation.

I do not, of course, have to follow the police view as to the result of the investigation and in fact in some cases I have not agreed with the Commissioner's conclusion. However, it is somewhat difficult to find otherwise in most instances when there is only available the various statements made by the persons involved to consider and that there is no opportunity to test the evidence.
That is the important point. The Ombudsman in New South Wales continued:

I have seen in a number of the reports and statements made by the police in the course of an investigation, a tendency to denigrate the complainant and attribute to him some sinister motive. This may be correct in some cases but in many the complaints appear to be genuine ones. Such comments are quite unnecessary and do not help in the carrying out of an impartial investigation.
To 30 June, 1979,-
that is, for the financial year 1978-79-
224 complaints were received.

By the way, it is interesting to note that in New South Wales in the following year-that is, in 1980-the number of complaints against the police increased from 224 to 741. The number of complaints more than trebled in that time. I do not know what the explanation for that is, whether people have become more aware of the ability of the Ombudsman to receive complaints or whether there has been an increase in the misbehaviour or alleged misbehaviour of police officers, but I assume it is the former. The Ombudsman in New South Wales went on to state:

As detailed earlier, the Ombudsman is limited in his powers under this Act, and has difficulties in making his own independent appraisal of the parties involved. There is no right to interview the various parties, other than perhaps the complainant, and any further investigation would be limited to determining whether the police investigation has been properly carried out.

Whilst I do not suggest for one moment that the Ombudsman should carry out a full scale investigation of these matters, I consider that at least there should be a right for him to investigate further if he considers that in the public interest he should do so coupled with the right to interview witnesses if he felt it to be necessary.

The Ombudsman in New South Wales went on to make a number of criticisms of the fact that a copy of the complaint in the name of the complainant is furnished to the policeman concerned and that people therefore are worried that there might be cases in which pressure is exerted on the complainant to withdraw his complaint. The Ombudsman in New South Wales stated:

In such event, if possible, I confirm this direct with the complainant but I do express concern that whilst I have no evidence that influence has been brought to bear on complainants to withdraw, this would be possible.

The 1980 report of the Ombudsman in New South Wales has not yet been published but it has been tabled in Parliament. In an article in the Sydney Morning Herld of 28 November 1980 the Ombudsman is reported to have stated in his 1980 report:

I consider that it is essential for the legislation to be amended so that the Ombudsman, where he is dissatisfied with the investigation performed by the police, has a right to investigate the matter for himself or direct that one of his officers does so. . . .

I think that is an important point. It has been embraced in sub-clause (3) of clause 27 of the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill, which is before us, if my interpretation is correct. That sub-clause states:
For the purposes of an investigation under this Part, the Ombudsman may, by notice in writing, require-
(c) a member, or an officer of a Department or prescribed authority,-
I assume that includes a policeman or a member of the Australian Federal Police-
who is, in the opinion of the Ombudsman, able to give information relevant to the investigation;
to attend before him at a time and place specified in the notice and there to answer questions relevant to the investigation.

In other words, under that sub-clause the Ombudsman would be able to investigate the complaint. I am not one who holds a great brief for the police force, my having been associated with the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties for many years. I was one of its foundation members and for some 13 years I was a member of the executive of that Council. I certainly became aware, if I had not been aware before I joined the Council, of many shortcomings in the behaviour of police officers. Having said that, I am aware also that in many ways policemen have fewer civil liberties than do other members of the community. They are unable to refuse to answer questions when cross-examined by their superiors. I draw the attention of the House to sub-clause (6) of clause 7 and the whole of clause 50 of the Bill. Sub-clause (6) of clause 7 states:

Where a member of the Australian Federal Police is directed . . . to furnish information, produce a document or record or answer a question, the member is not excused from complying with the direction on the ground that-
(a) the furnishing of the information, the production of the document or record or the answering of the question-
(i) would be contrary to the public interest; or
(ii) might make him liable to a penalty; or
(b) the information, the production of the document or record or the answer to the question might tend to incriminate him . . . .

So, under that provision, a police officer would be in a worse position in terms of civil liberties than would be an ordinary member of the community who, as I understand the law, is not forced to answer questions for the purpose of incriminating himself. The Bill goes on to state that the answers to such questions are not admissible in evidence against such an officer in any civil or criminal proceedings other than proceedings for an offence in relation to a breach of discipline; in other words, if he refuses to answer such questions. Whilst that provides such an officer with some protection, I argue that it is not complete protection. For example, in a case of two police officers being charged with conspiring to obtain a bribe from a member of the public, under this provision those officers would be forced to answer questions which were incriminating and, whilst the answers could not be used in evidence against those officers, they could be used against their alleged co-conspirators. My interpretation of the proposed legislation might be wrong, but the way I interpret it people in fact will be forced to incriminate themselves in some way.

I am sufficiently a libertarian to believe that civil liberties should be extended also to members of the police force. As far as the police force is concerned, the important thing really is for people who misbehave to be cleaned out of it. That is not easily done. It is generally said-I suppose it is the sort of thing that politicians ought always to say-that the vast majority of police officers are terribly honest, sincere, able and good people and it is just the odd person in the police force who misbehaves. I have not had extensive contact with members of the police force, but I have had sufficient contact with them-I have listened to them in courts and so on-to believe that many police officers, probably the majority, at some stage perjure themselves when giving evidence. I am not suggesting that they perjure themselves in the sense of trying to frame an innocent person; they are completely convinced that the person concerned is guilty, or they might even have been present when the person concerned committed a certain act. But I believe that for the purpose of gaining a conviction before a magistrate or a jury they will perjure themselves, they will make up a story.

Let me quickly give an example of this. I refer to my first contact with the New South Wales police force. Many years ago, in the 1940s, I was involved in a demonstration in connection with the Sydney University Labor Club of which I was the President at the time. It was not a big demonstration but the police expected that it would be. They expected the wharfies to join the demonstration. Therefore, members of Squad 21, an aggressive part of the police force at that time-possibly it still is-were dressed up in what they considered to be wharfies clothing. The wharfies did not turn up for the demonstration. Some 30 or 40 university students were there in Wynyard Park near the Dutch Consulate. The demonstration concerned the attempt at that time by the Netherlands to re-enter Indonesia. Members of No. 21 Division moved in on the students, roughed them up and arrested some 15 of them, including me. In my case, I took the number of a uniformed policeman who assaulted a student. The next thing that happened was that two detectives in plain clothes arrested me and took me away. I was later charged with assaulting a policeman, resisting arrest and using offensive language. These charges were not true in my case although there is no doubt that such charges were true in some cases. It is true that some people did use offensive language or did resist arrest.

It is interesting to note that in every case the police gave the same sort of evidence. Fifteen people were arrested and in every case the policeman would get up in the box and say: 'I am a constable in the New South Wales Police Force. I was proceeding along Margaret Street in a westerly direction at 3.40 p.m. I saw the defendant wildly gesticulating'. That is a lovely phrase. The policeman would then say: 'I approached the defendant and asked him to desist. I said: ''I am a constable in the New South Wales Police Force and I tell you to desist''.' I notice that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden), who is an ex-member of a police force, is entering the chamber. In every case the defendant was supposed to have said: 'You are nothing but a so-and-so copper' and then another word referring to parts of the female genitalia. This evidence was given in 14 out of 15 cases. Even at that time I was known for my rather strong anti-communist attitude. After much consideration I was charged with saying to a detective in plain clothes who looked like a wharf labourer: 'You are nothing but a so-and-so commo'. I was charged with using the same swear words but the word 'commo' was substituted for 'copper'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is imagination.

—That is imagination and it was the height of imagination at that time in the New South Wales Police Force. I hope that things have improved. But the important point is that many people in New South Wales and many people all over the country know that the police have given false evidence against them in court. These people ought to be able to take some action against the police.

SPEECH.PARA: This brings me to a question which has just recently been raised again, the tape recording and videotaping of alleged confessions. I can see problems associated with that. One of the problems that has been raised with me by a judge whom I respect very much for his views on civil liberties is that normally a person going into the box can refuse to answer questions put to him. He can refuse to say anything. However, if a videotape is made of an interview at a police station apparently that videotape could be submitted as evidence. That person may have made statements or admissions at the police station which he would not be prepared to make during cross-examination in court. I think that is obviously one of the difficulties.

Many of us have heard stories about the police. Until the last election a very well known ex-member of the New South Wales Police Force, the former honourable member for Hunter, was a member of this place. We have heard many stories about police. I think it is terribly important that this Federal legislation is made to work. It is also important that the States take note of the legislation and, if it works, introduce similar legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike my honourable friend, the member for Prospect (Dr Klugman), who just concluded his speech, I enter this debate as an unashamed advocate and supporter of the Australian police forces. I would like to stress the words of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in introducing the Bill in the Senate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill should be regarded as in no way a reflection on the Australian Federal Police or its members who, with the fewest possible exceptions, perform their difficult tasks with honesty, zeal and devotion to duty.

Any police force, and I think the Australian Federal Police in particular, has a difficult and exacting task to perform which often involves personal danger. As Gilbert of Gilbert and Sullivan fame put it: 'A policeman's lot is not a happy one'. I repeat, the Minister said this Bill should in no way be regarded as a reflection on the force or on its high reputation for honesty, effectiveness and devotion to duty.

In the few remarks that I want to address to the House I wish to refer to the point that the honourable member for Prospect raised concerning the use of tapes. I would like to say something about the whole issue of the adapting of police methods to modern technology and in particular to micro-electronic technology based on the silicon chip. Perhaps this is particularly appropriate on the day when the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) has just announced a project by the National Semiconductor company looking towards the setting up of a chip facility in the Australian Capital Territory. In this respect I have in mind in particular the desirability of police officers using tape recorders, not video equipment, in investigative and interrogation situations. In a spirited debate concerning the much maligned police 'verbal' on Sydney radio only last Friday, Detective Sergeant Tony Lauer, the President of the New South Wales Police Association, finished his remarks by saying:
Then the only fair thing to do would be to provide each of the 9,000 policemen in New South Wales with a tape recorder.
With that his radio opponent, barrister Shaun Flood, heartily agreed.

In my view, that is bang on. I am certain that in the great majority of cases in the long run this would be to the benefit of police forces and not a hindrance although I am aware many police officers would initially see it as such. I am convinced that a very significant contribution would be made to police credibility-this is the key thing-if in fact there were a tape recorder in every policeman's pocket. A small recorder would be the honest policeman's-and that means the overwhelming majority of policemen-best defence in a complaint situation and in all other aspects of investigative and interrogative police work. Also it would be of great value in subsequent court recordings.

The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) in his second reading speech, and my colleague the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron) a few moments ago, acknowledged the contribution that His Honour Mr Justice Michael Kirby's Law Reform Commission made to the proposals in the legislation. Only recently-at the time of the last week of sitting-in a speech to an international forum of forensic scientists, Mr Justice Kirby stressed the importance of taped evidence in courts. He spoke of sound recordings-and possibly video recordings-as potentially 'a tremendous weapon' in the fight against crime.

I am sure that is absolutely right. What I am stressing is that all along the line, from investigatory discussions in the field, through interrogation, to the courts, it is the credibility of the police force which stands to gain. I am certain that police officers, understandably initially suspicious of such gadgetry, particularly the pocket recorder I have talked about, would come to see the gains all round in combating crime and in underwriting police credibility, and would come to see that these gains would far outweigh the disadvantages.

A report of a British royal commission in January this year, along with other sources, points to problems in this area-the honourable member for Prospect pointed to some of these. There are two main problems firstly, the cost, and, secondly, the area of authenticating tapes, of preventing the tampering with and editing of tapes. Those are problems which I am confident-indeed I know-are not beyond the scope of modern micro-electronic technology. In this matter, therefore, I believe the ball is in the court of police officers at all levels. I believe they should accept the aid of modern technology and gain the benefits in terms of the more effective combating of crime and-I cannot stress this too much-the gains in the area of police credibility which this technology offers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in support of both of these Bills, the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill 1981 and the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill 1981. I believe they will provide a workable system whereby the rights of police officers and the public are protected. The appeals provisions for members of the public to make complaints against police provide several avenues by which action may be taken. The public may appeal either to the Ombudsman or to the Internal Investigation Division of the Australian Federal Police. Further provision is made for the responsible Minister to order a special investigation of a specific complaint. The detailed procedures set down for the investigation of any complaint should ensure that all such matters are handled thoroughly and effectively while at the same time preserving the rights of both the police and public. Where any complaint is made to a police officer, the Ombudsman must be notified. Through this legislation the Ombudsman's role is strengthened and extended, and should result in improved safeguards for members of the public in their dealings with the police.

SPEECH.PARA: The rights of citizens are further improved under the provisions of clause 4 of the Bill for an Act to amend the Australian Federal Police Act 1979. Under this clause, members of the police force must at all times wear identification numbers on the front of their uniforms and there is provision for a penalty of $500 for failure to do so. The arrangements for the investigation of complaints by means of the Ombudsman, the Internal Investigation Division of the Australian Federal Police and ministerial action should ensure that an effective mechanism has been established.

The rights of police officers have been enhanced by provision for the Commonwealth to assume vicarious liability for the actions of police in the performance of their duties. In this way, the Commonwealth, like all other employers, will be liable in respect of tort committed by an employee. In large measure the objectives of the Law Reform Commission report of 1978 have been enacted, with minor variations resulting from the creation of the Australian Federal Police in 1979. These measures will be welcomed by members of the police force as well as the general community.

This legislation is the culmination of a lengthy procedure for the establishment of the Australian Federal Police Force. We may recall that the proposal to establish a national police force was reactivated following the bombing of the Hilton Hotel in Sydney on 13 February 1978. Sir Robert Mark's inquiry into the organisation of police resources in the Commonwealth was an urgent matter and the report was tabled on 13 April 1978. The Government acted swiftly to set up a task force to give effect to its in-principle decision to establish a single federal police force incorporating the existing Australian Capital Territory and Commonwealth police forces. The Australian Federal Police Bill 1979 became law in June 1979, and the force was established with Sir Colin Woods as commissioner.

The Bills under debate today will extend the effectiveness of our police force. They provide members of the general public with additional safeguards and rights of appeal in their dealings with the police. The rights of police officers are protected throughout the complaints procedure and are further strengthened under the provisions whereby Commonwealth liability is extended.

I want to refer briefly to the police who operate in the Australian Capital Territory. They have extremely close relations with the community at all levels. The new amalgamated Australian Federal Police has continued the tradition of the previous forces and has provided the community with an excellent service. To give one example, on 28 February this year officers of the police force in the Australian Capital Territory held a fete on behalf of the Multiple Sclerosis Association. This fete had wide support from members of the Australian Federal Police. I think this demonstrates their commitment to work very closely with the community. I have noticed that over the last couple of weeks members of the Australian Federal Police have participated in the Canberra Week festivities. There is a regular community broadcast program on our local television station, Channel 7. These are just examples which demonstrate the involvement of the police force in the Australian Capital Territory.

One point I think needs to be emphasised. Section 69 of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 provides for the establishment of a police liaison advisory committee for the Australian Capital Territory. That committee has not been set up, despite the fact that the legislation became law in June 1979. In March 1980 the Minister for the Capital Territory sent a message to the House of Assembly regarding the proposed committee, seeking the Assembly's advice on the proposal to establish such a committee. The House of Assembly called for the early establishment of the police liaison advisory committee. The proposed committee is to be chaired by a commissioner and will have five members of the House of Assembly on it. Its functions are set out by regulation. They are to encourage community awareness and understanding of such functions of the Australian Federal Police as relate to the provision of police services in the Australian Capital Territory and to advise the Minister on those. I ask the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to give urgent consideration to the establishment of this advisory committee. The recommendation for its establishment is set out clearly in legislation and does need to be activated.

I must also provide a cautionary note in relation to the police services in the Australian Capital Territory. When the Australian Federal Police was established, the Government gave a commitment that the police officers of the Australian Capital Territory and the community would not be disadvantaged by the establishment of the Australian Federal Police. The Australian Capital Territory was to be the responsibility of a separate deputy commissioner with certain autonomy. However I understand that lately the officers of that division have been used on national matters. For example, I have had information that about 200 officers from various parts of Australia are being sent to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, but the big majority of those are from the Australian Capital Territory. I hope that if officers from the Territory are being used for these national functions, the Australian Capital Territory force will get compensation.

I conclude by recommending to the Minister that the police liaison advisory committee be set up immediately and that the Federal Government continue to retain the identity of an Australian Capital Territory community police force.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not intend to oppose the Australian Tourist Commission Amendment Bill. However, it intends to take the opportunity to point out the Government's deficiencies in the whole tourist industry. No one, least of all a rational party such as the Australian Labor Party-which might be of some interest to some honourable members opposite-could argue against the need to increase the number of commissioners from nine to 10 or to increase the number of Territory representatives from two to three. I am pleased to see that the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) is sitting at the table, because we consider that Canberra is one of the very important tourist destinations of Australia for many reasons which I need not underline at the moment. In fact, my colleague, the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) would like to speak in a fuller fashion later in the debate about the charms and delights of Canberra. The Opposition is quite delighted that the number of commissioners is being increased to accommodate the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. Of course, a good deal of their revenue comes from tourism. Such moves are indeed sensible. So too is the third aim of the Bill to bring the financial provisions of the Act into line with legislation covering comparable statutory authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that this Government will be looking towards redressing the very sexist imbalance of the Australian Tourist Commission. Given the comments of the Minister for the Capital Territory over the last couple of days on sexism issues, I am sure he would back me up in that regard. At present there are nine commissioners of whom only one is a female. Does that reflect community participation in tourism? Of course it does not. The Commission will be the poorer while this state of affairs exists.

I would like to come directly to the question of the economics of tourism. The most recent and comprehensive report is that put out by the Bureau of Industry Economics. It is fairly old because the latest figures that are available are those for 1973-74. I would like to refer to the fourth research report entitled 'The Economic Significance of Tourism in Australia in 1979'. There is very little doubt that tourism impacts dramatically on our economy. In 1973-74 tourism contributed 2.6 per cent of gross domestic product. It employed 2.4 per cent of the work force and accounted for 3.2 per cent of indirect tax revenue. These figures, which have been referred to before by the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) place tourism at just about the level of the motor manufacturing industry and just behind the mining industry. Obviously it is a very significant industry.

The Bureau of Industrial Economics further predicts that by 1985 overseas tourist spending in Australia will rise from 20 per cent to 40 per cent of total tourism spending. That is the amount contributed by overseas visitors. By 1985 employment in the tourist industry will increase from 2.4 per cent to about 8 per cent of the work force and will add 60,000 new jobs. Its contribution to the gross domestic product will rise by 80 per cent to about 4.5 per cent of our GDP. Obviously, as is shown by those bald figures, tourism is a very significant industry.

A great deal of informed and uninformed debate has taken place on the possible tourist boom. One thing that is certain is that it is one of the prime growth industries and, as such, we in Australia ought to be capitalising on the expansion. Mr Deputy Speaker, the fact is-you will excuse the tourist pun-we are missing the boat quite dramatically. Including the payment for fares, the amount spent in a year by the millions of international travellers on tourist related industries is estimated to be the staggering figure of $325,000m, or more than six times the annual value of Australia's gross domestic product. The sad fact is that Australia currently extracts much less than one per cent of all international tourist expenditures-in fact about 0.3 per cent, a very tiny proportion of the tourist dollar. That is something that the Opposition deplores.

Even in the Pacific area, where I would have thought just as a matter of fact that Australia would be the leader, our share of tourism is dropping. In 1970 our share of tourism in this market was 4.7 per cent. By 1978 it had dropped to 3.8 per cent, showing just how rapidly we were losing out to the other Asian Pacific countries who are so much more aware of tourism as an industry than we are. The honourable member for Bowman (Mr Jull) is going to join in this debate. I am sure that he shares the views of the Opposition and the optimism that it would like to express in tourism as a growth industry in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a very good man.

—He is a very good member; I agree with the Minister. I do not know what he is doing on the other side of the House. As a result of our failure to exploit the Pacific area, a great many off-shore venues for conventions, seminars, workshops and other events have become a great deal more attractive than Australia. Local tour operators, convention venue entrepreneurs, tourism support industries and the airlines themselves face a great loss of business because of this. For instance, seven nights with all travel and accommodation expenses from Sydney cost less than $360 in Fiji and less than $300 in New Zealand. But five nights all-in cost about $400 in Hobart and more than $700 in Darwin; about 30 per cent higher than, for example, Singapore.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last Budget the Fraser Government allocated to tourism less than $20m. It is interesting to note that the Government gets back $10m of that $20m every 12 months in gateway tax, the $10 tax it collects from people leaving Australia. So the net contribution to tourism in the last Budget was around the $10m mark. I mentioned previously that this industry contributes as much as the motor industry. When we look at the hundreds of millions of dollars expended in promoting that industry I wonder just what the Government is doing in failing to promote tourism as an industry. I know that the argument is quite reasonable that without manufacturing industries we would not have as many people in work; we would not have people wanting holidays; and that tourism perhaps would suffer. I think there is a great imbalance between the $10m net for tourism and the hundreds of millions of dollars expended in many manufacturing industries.

This Government is neglecting to foster an important industry. It lacks the imagination and the foresight necessary to capitalise on this growing industry, not only an industry which is economically significant but also one which gives so much pleasure to the community. The whole leisure industry is crying out for the type of leadership that an entrepreneurial government could give it, such as was given it by the Labor Government from 1972 to 1975. I give credit to the present Minister for Industry and Commerce. At least he has some understanding of the tourist industry and has taken some positive steps in recent times. The Bill we are now debating is part of the new-found interest in the tourism business, but it might well be a case of too little too late. I ask the Government where it was in the tourism area from 1975 to 1978. Perhaps it might say it was on holidays. If it was on a holiday it was doing a lot better than many other people who could not afford a holiday.

According to figures from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, growth in tourism in Australia fell last year. The increase in the number of overseas visitors arriving in Australia was 15.9 per cent compared with a growth rate of 25.9 per cent in 1979. Revenue growth from those tourists fell also. In 1979 the figure was 27.4 per cent compared with 19.1 per cent last year. In the same OECD report there is a note of optimism that as the world economy improves so will interest in travel pick up and so will we see a stronger growth rate in the tourist industry. This is in line with predictions previously quoted from the BIE report that by 1985 overseas tourist spending in Australia will rise from the present 20 per cent to 40 per cent of total tourism expenditure. Will we be geared up for this upsurge of interest in travel-not just travel but the whole spectrum of the leisure industry?

In 1972 under the Whitlam Government, in those years of Camelot in Australia, the people of Australia saw the advent of the first Federal Ministry for Tourism and Recreation under the direction of the late Frank Stewart and with it the recognition that there was a vital role for government in this area. In that time the role of the Australian Tourist Commission was expanded and with it went a brief to step up the promotion of Australia overseas and on the domestic market through the program 'Australia-Land of things to see and do'. By 1975 some $2.34m had been provided in grants and loans for the development of man-made attractions such as Sovereign Hill, Old Sydney Town, Lachlan Vintage Village and Port Arthur.

To the purist, these man-made attractions might seem gauche and almost artificial, but they are essential ingredients in an overall tourism strategy. Our heritage, the colonial frontier people that we were, is encapsulated in places such as Sovereign Hill and Old Sydney Town. These places give Australians of today as well as overseas visitors a dioramic view of our past. Of course it is preferable to visit these man-made attractions in conjunction with the real thing. I might say that that is nowhere more evident than in my home town of Parramatta. In Parramatta some of Australia's real antiquity reposes. Within a radius of less than half a mile exists a cottage that was built by John Macarthur back in 1791-it is the oldest house in Australia; it is still standing--

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good Liberal, too.
—I do not know whether he was a Liberal. He was sent back to England for terrible behaviour.

—Order! The Chair is reluctant to interrupt the honourable member in his oratorical safari, but the Chair would be derelict in its duty if it did not observe that even though we are debating the Australian Tourist Commission Amendment Bill and honourable members may distance themselves from relevance, the honourable member is required to address his remarks to the Bill.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, my argument might seem to you to be rather tenuous but we are talking about the promotion of tourism in Australia, which is what the Australian Tourist Commission is all about.
—The honourable member is addressing his attention to the Bill. He may proceed. The Chair will hear him.

—I suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that when I spoke about man-made and artificial types of tourist attractions, I was suggesting that in Parramatta we have a marvellous collection of real antiquity which is something to which overseas visitors should be attracted. The reason I mentioned it was that I was hoping that this Government might be prepared to consider subsidising the development of the tourism industry within this part of Sydney. The three cottages to which I wish to refer are: Elizabeth Farm, which was a house built by John Macarthur and where in fact the Australian wool industry started; within 100 yards of that is a house called Experiment Farm Cottage, which was built by James Ruse-that is where the Australian wheat industry commenced-and within a range of a quarter of a mile is Hambledon Cottage, which was built by John Macarthur for his daughter, Elizabeth, in 1815. Sitting in one small area is a marvellous collection of Australia's real antiquity, looking for development, looking for the injection of government funds to bring this little group of cottages up to something that is really significant. I suggest that to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, in passing.

SPEECH.PARA: I now return to the man-made tourist facilities. We may rave all we like about the grandeur and beauty of Australia's natural attractions, but the fact is that very few international tourists seek them out. I suspect that the cost of domestic air fares, despite the Minister's protestations to the contrary, are the prime reason for the neglect of our far-flung natural attractions. I am supported in my claim that such places as Ayers Rock and the Great Barrier Reef are neglected by overseas visitors by a Qantas Airways Ltd survey conducted on departing foreign tourists in 1973. This survey revealed, quite disappointingly, that Ayers Rock was visited by a mere 2 per cent and the Great Barrier Reef, which is in your home State, Mr Deputy Speaker, by only 4 per cent of such visitors. That is rather depressing when we consider that the Great Barrier Reef-I know that the honourable member for Bowman has spoken very eloquently on this in the past-is one of the really great attractions of this world. It is one of the wonders of the world. It is a really magnificent attraction for tourists and yet only 4 per cent of our international visitors are going there. Of course, the two-airline agreement which is to be updated will entrench this position probably for another 10 years unless the Minister in charge of tourism is able to convince his colleagues to do otherwise.

Whilst it is true to say that this situation might have improved since 1973, it is still evident that most foreign tourists spend their time and money in the capital cities, with Sydney being the most visited. I could not really blame them for that. We are talking about the great cosmopolitan cities of the world, and of course Sydney is just slightly ahead of Canberra. Really, it is one of the most beautiful cities of the world. It is no wonder that overseas visitors go there in droves.

I suggest that by investing money in the likes of Sovereign Hill and Old Sydney Town we ensure some diversification of the tourist dollars-a distribution to regional areas, if you like. I imagine that the coalition government would favour such a strategy. Yet we have seen little, if any, support for the continuation of the former Labor Government's initiatives.

Who would deny the employment opportunities created by these man-made operations; that is, regional job opportunities, which is giving employment to people in country areas where unemployment is worst? Also to be considered is the accommodation which springs up around these attractions and with it even more employment opportunities. Tourism and leisure activities filter right through the economic system. The BIE report's conclusions stated:
. . . tourism is already of considerable significance to the Australian economy with direct or indirect effects on almost every industry.

It has been stated that tourism or leisure, or the two together, make a contribution to all 109 industry groups in Australia. Any Australian Government ignores tourism at its peril. Given the evidence of all the economic indicators which show the value of tourism to the national economy, I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there is an overwhelming argument for the reinstatement of the Department of Tourism and Recreation. Certainly, after 1983 when Labour is in office, we will be looking to do just that. By that time, the leisure industry will have grown to such proportions that it will not be able to be ignored, as seems to be presently the case.

Let me list some of the reasons why I believe that nothing less than a fully operational Federal department is capable of effectively harnessing the exciting potentials of the leisure industry. Quite naturally, my top priority is employment opportunity. Here, in an area of our lives which affects so many other industries, a Federal government has a unique opportunity to stimulate the economy and create employment simply by investing in a man-made attractions and other types of tourist facilities.

Leisure is a very labour intensive area. The BIE report pointed this out. Areas such as restaurants, hotels and clubs are very labour intensive. I point out to anybody who is interested that the reason New South Wales has the lowest unemployment rate in Australia is to a great extent because of the leisure industry which has built up there. Presently there are 33,000 permanent jobs provided in registered clubs in New South Wales with some 100,000 more temporary jobs. It is very unlikely that anybody will ever create a machine that will make beds or serve meals. That is the beauty of the leisure industry. It is totally labour intensive. While I am on the subject of labour and the leisure industry, I mention the oft-quoted lament that penalty rates inhibit the industry. A very excellent report was produced by Roger Kirby who was then the boss of Travelodge Australia Ltd. He pointed out that it is a total furphy to suggest that penalty rates are holding back the accommodation industry in Australia. It is just wrong. No less a person than Professor Brian Johns, the Director of the BIE, stated:
The report showed that the prices of tourist services in Australia are not significantly higher than in other developed countries.

Again I quote from a Press release issued by the Minister last year when he visited Tokyo. He cited figures from a world survey conducted by the economic research department of the Union Bank of Switzerland. He stated:

Our tourist industry can compete favourably with other alternative tourist destinations around the world . . . The general level of prices in Sydney was ranked lower than those in 33 of the 45 cities (surveyed).

The important and most significant part of that is that we can provide such competitive prices within a framework of a high living standard. There is absolutely no reason why Australian workers ought to lower their living standards in order to attract the tourist dollar. Consequently there is no good reason why penalty rates should be abandoned. They were hard won.

TALK.START.PARA: —For some time now we have been considerably concerned at the cuts in expenditure to the States for community health services that have been implemented by this Federal Government. The facts are that nationally in 1975 $59.5m was made available to the States for the community health service. In 1980-81 the same figure-$59.5m-was allocated. Of course, when one allows for inflation this means in real terms that there was a cut of some 39 per cent. In New South Wales the relevant figures were $25.8m in 1975 and $24.9m in 1980-81-a cut in real terms of 41 per cent. In addition to these cuts which in effect have a double-banked effect, in 1975 the Federal Government provided 90 per cent of expenditure under the formula and the States 10 per cent. In 1977 this Fraser Federal Government cut the Commonwealth contribution to this formula to 75 per cent with 25 per cent to be provided by the States. In 1978 this Government went even further and made it a 50-50 arrangement or a dollar for dollar basis. The effect of this financially with regard to New South Wales is: In 1980-81 the Federal Government made $24.9m available and the State matched it with $24.9m-that is almost $50m. But the State had to put in $25m. In 1975 to get the same $50m the Federal Government would have put in $45m and the State only $5m. Little wonder that New South Wales and other States are having great difficulty in maintaining their community health centre services.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very concerned at the effect of this in my electorate of Cunningham in the Illawarra area in New South Wales where we have 29 community health centres. In 1976 there was a staff of approximately 200. This has been broken down to 167 by 1981. In this financial year New South Wales is experiencing a $1.2m shortfall. The New South Wales Health Commission has been forced to implement a policy of no replacements of vacancies as they occur through resignations or even annual leave, accouchement leave and so on. If the present rate of decrease continues the service will be down to a staff of 140 by 1 July this year. These cuts, of course, have been in direct care services. The Press release put out by the combined unions employed in the community health centres states:

This means that many areas may be without services such as nursing care for the sick and dying, support of the mentally ill, physically and mentally handicapped and in some cases school medical and baby health services. In addition preventive programmes such as pre-natal and parenting education, coronary screening, breast self-examination, health education to schools and community, anti-smoking, special playgroups, relaxation, diabetic counselling etc. will be severely curtailed . . .

I want to draw the attention of the House to an article in the Illawarra Mercury of last week which is headlined: 'Cost cutting could add to suffering-Dying cancer patient may lose her aide'. The article states:
Mrs Barbara Walsh cried yesterday when she got the news her Community Health nurse might not be calling again after tomorrow.
Mrs Walsh, of Harry Graham Drive, Mt Kembla, has terminal cancer. She has been bedridden for 12 months.
Her doctor calls three or four times a day to ease her suffering.

Mrs Walsh's nurse is one of 14 Health Commission relief employees whose job is on the line because of these Federal Government cuts in this vital service. I want to condemn at this stage the mendacious role played by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume). I quote what the honourable member said from the Illawarra Mercury of last week. The headline states: 'Govt couldn't run a lavatory, says Baume'. The article went on to say of the honourable member:
He said the Federal Government has increased its contribution to community health services this year by 21 per cent, . . . to $24.9 million.

All I can say is that his figures are as shonky as his language is intemperate and his claimed facts are mendacious. I have put on the record what has actually occurred since 1975 on this matter. In New South Wales the cuts have been of the nature of 40 per cent under the Fraser Government. We realise that this is part of a wider attack on resource allocations for community health services, public housing and so on. As the Treasury said, if the resources boom continues with a tremendous demand on private infrastructure capital finances and also with a demand on the States to provide the infrastructure for this development we can see many more of these cuts coming up in the next Budget. I appeal to the House by asking: Do we really want to kill and to terminate the community health centres that have done so much to improve the health of our people? I look to the day when the community health centres in Australia as set up by the Whitlam Labor Government in 1974 and 1975 can not only provide these preventative health services and these home nursing care services that I have talked about but also can actually employ doctors and specialists in them so that they can provide a real alternative to fee-for-service medicine in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Often in debates in this House the problems of the aged pensioners of our community are neglected. I take the opportunity tonight to describe the debilitating experiences of one of my constituents, Mr Albert Bruce, in his successful attempt to avoid losing the fringe benefits of his age pension. In May 1980 Mr Bruce and his wife received a combined United Kingdom age pension of $69 a week which was $1 more than the $68 they were allowed to earn before they lost their fringe benefits. Acting on the advice of the Department of Social Security, Mr Bruce immediately wrote to the United Kingdom pension authorities requesting that his total benefit be reduced to $68 a week. This was done by the United Kingdom Department of Health and Social Security. Following this desperate measure Mr Bruce was most upset to find that the Department of Social Security immediately invoked a provision of the Social Services Act which states that when the Director-General is of the opinion that a pensioner has directly or indirectly deprived himself of income in order to qualify for or obtain a pension at a higher rate he may deem the amount involved to be income for a period of 12 months of the deprivation.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Bruce then wrote back to the Department pointing out that his United Kingdom pension had been reduced. Honourable member's should note that this was a reduction of only $1 a week. His pension had been reduced in order that he would not lose what were to him his essential fringe benefits. The Department then informed him that as a result of income received from investments plus exchange rate fluctuations relating to the United Kingdom pension the combined income of him and his wife meant that their Australian pensions must be substantially reduced and they would lose their fringe benefits. Mr Bruce, after some considerable correspondence, was able to prove to the Department that he no longer received investment income but the Department stood firm on the exchange rate requirements. After months of wearying disputation Mr Bruce then sought the help of the Ombudsman and his Federal member. Finally, in August the Department of Social Security admitted its errors and Mr and Mrs Bruce's pensions and their fringe benefits were restored.

My main purpose in bringing up this matter tonight is in order that Mr Bruce's battle with an unyielding legislative machine should not be in vain. His case is not an isolated one. I have had a considerable number of my constituents complain to me about the penalty provisions. Whilst it is true that the Department does not stand in a good light in the case I have mentioned I do not wish to blame public servants for bad government. Many thousands of age pensioners are suffering reductions in pensions and losing their fringe benefits as a result of these penny-pinching penal provisions. I call on the Government to revoke these savage and inhumane means test provisions of the Social Services Act and to restore some measure of dignity and security to many Australians in their retirement years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The letter to Mr Smyth quite clearly states:

SPEECH.PARA: It has now been confirmed that you have the required Theatre of War service to make application for a Service pension on attaining sixty years of age.

My constituent finds himself in a difficult position. He retired from his work on the basis of what he thought to be his eligibility for a Service pension. The Government should in some way seek to make up to Mr Smyth what he would otherwise have qualified for in the form of a Service pension. I believe that in justice some way around this problem ought to be found so that Mr Smyth can gain the benefits of what he thought he would receive.

That is what that Government said when the Commonwealth granted a 21 per cent increase, but now the honourable member, by some magnificent intellectual capacity which he displays with such regularity to this House, says that because total funding this year is lower than it was in 1976 the sackings in the Illawarra health region are directly the responsibility of the Federal Government. That is arrant nonsense and he knows it because there has been a 21 per cent increase in funding.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact is that the New South Wales Health Commission has overspent that increase in regions other than the Illawarra region. Overspending has not occurred in the Illawarra region. Because it is the whipping boy of the State Government it has to carry the overspending in the rest of New South Wales. It always comes last in health spending under the Labor Government of New South Wales. It has to carry the can for overspending in the rest of the State. For the honourable member for Cunningham to pretend that there has been a dark, mischievous plot in the Federal Government's making an alleged cut is arrant nonsense and deception. The honourable member is deliberately seeking to deceive the people of Illawarra about the fact that the New South Wales Government has proved itself incompetent to handle a 21 per cent rise in funding this year for community health service. That kind of incompetence and deception are typical of the Labor Party, and certainly of the honourable member.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the House tonight about two young men called Robert and Bill. Robert lost a leg when he was 14 years old. Since then he has had an artificial leg which he finds very difficult to wear because it gives him a very bad back, as do crutches also. After he lost his leg he could not settle back in school so, quite unqualified at 15 years, he took a job. The only one he could get was driving a fork lift machine, but when there was not enough work for the machine he had to go down into the store room and help out there. He could not cope with the lifting involved so he had to leave that position. As he could not get another job he applied for the dole. He got a job with a tow truck company. This involved long hours, poor pay and offered no overtime for weekend work. He stayed as long as he could put up with it but then had to leave and go back on the dole again. He was on the dole for two years but not once during that time was a job offered to him by the Commonwealth Employment Service. His mother's mother took ill in Queanbeyan. The son drove her up to visit and then went back again. On the day he was away from home a field officer called to see him. The husband rang and explained where he was, what he was doing and when he would be home but Robert was taken off the dole. It took a hell of a long fight to get him back on it again. He was taken off the dole because he was out of Victoria for whatever reason or however briefly. It took six weeks to get Robert back on the dole. Three years ago he applied for an invalid pension. He was knocked back. He has not worked now for over 12 months. In the last seven years of misery and pain he has worked for about 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: Every time he applied for a job he was told that they needed someone who was not handicapped. Robert is not handicapped; he is disabled by the loss of his leg. His handicap is given to him by us-by the society in which he lives. We applied for the pension for him again but he was knocked back again. As his mother points out: 'Because he has lost a leg he does not count as a human being any more'. She also said that Robert had reached the stage where he goes down with his dole form and feels as though he is a criminal. Robert is 21. He probably has another 50-odd years in front of him. Is he supposed to live on the dole forever or are we prepared to train Robert and all the Roberts of this world in the work with which they can cope bearing in mind their disabilities? It makes a mockery of the words in the second reading speech earlier tonight by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner). The Minister brought out the fact that everyone no matter how disabled he is-physically or mentally-is entitled to a decent standard of living, to social security and to the right to live and not just to exist. Robert and all the other Roberts will be interested to hear the Minister's plans for their rights to become as self-reliant as possible. His plans are for them to have economic and social security and to have a chance for a decent level of living because they are certainly not getting these things in today's climate. It is not enough for the Minister to prate about human rights. A government is supposed to do something concrete to help Robert.

I shall leave Robert for the moment. Let us have a look at the position of Bill who is 26. He has a long history of mental instability but in between being institutionalised has fought very hard to work. He is an intelligent man and has held several responsible jobs. However, when the stress becomes heavy he loses his job, goes back on the dole and goes back into hospital. Some time ago he tried to commit suicide but simply succeeded in causing himself dreadful damage. It will be years before he is physically fit. Because he was on the dole at the time he gets the sickness benefit only at the rate of unemployment benefit. He needs complete care. He has to be lifted out of bed. He has to be taken to the physiotherapist twice a week. He needs a bedroom, which he has not got. His pensioner mother has a small one-bedroom cottage. Why cannot he go on to the invalid pension at least until he is fit? Why do we have to so humiliate and harass those who are least able to bear the burdens? What about Bill's future? What about his human rights? I challenge this Government to take up the responsibility of ensuring that those who are disabled have the right to live and not just to exist; make the Minister's words of today come true. The Government should give them the right to economic security and a decent standard of living. This Government is known for its great and humane rhetoric and is condemned for its failure to follow through with action.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the minute remaining in this adjournment debate I would like to underline the points I made in my speech earlier this evening by quoting from the Budget figures which dramatise the increase in spending on community health services this year. The table on page 90 of the Budget Speech sets out that the allocation for community health services this year is up $12.1m from $55.3m to $67.5m which is a rise of 22 per cent for Australia. For New South Wales there is an increase from $20.4m to $24.9m, a rise of $4.5m on a matching grant basis which represents a 21 per cent increase. The new total of $24.9m, as I said earlier, was regarded by the New South Wales Government as sufficient at least to maintain the standard last year for community health services in that State. Any cuts in services that have taken place subsequently are entirely due to the inability of the New South Wales Government to keep within its 21 per cent higher budget.
